Marjane Satrapi's acclaimed 2003 autobiographical graphic novel series has been turned into one of the most complexly moving animated films I've ever seen.
The best thing you can say about Mad Money is that it has a good cast. The worst thing you can say about it is that the cast is extremely ill-used.
The romantic comedy 27 Dresses will work best for people who have never seen a romantic comedy. If you have, you might find it amusing to tally up the steals -- I mean, homages.
Nanking does justice to this tragedy even though it makes the mistake of mixing the testimony of actual participants with staged readings from actors subbing for real people.

The Bucket List is a movie for oldsters that, paradoxically, looks as if it was made for 15-year-olds. If this is what is meant in Hollywood as "thinking outside the box," then it's time to get a new box.

Borderline incomprehensible and often exasperatingly arty, Youth Without Youth is nevertheless a movie that, somehow, successfully conveys a great deal of heartbreak. It's a personal film in the best and worst senses.

Sprawling yet cramped, There Will Be Blood may not be the best movie of the year, but it's certainly the strangest. It evokes passing comparisons to everything from Giant to Citizen Kane but it's impossible to pigeonhole.
Honeydripper, is medium-grade [John] Sayles.
The Great Debaters succeeds in bringing a lump to the throat without, as is de rigueur these days, insulting our intelligence.
This is one of those stories that, on some primal level, goes straight to the heart.

This second Jerry Bruckheimer National Treasure adventure, feebly directed by Jon Turtletaub, is no better than the first -- which means it will probably be creamed by critics and make a jillion dollars.
Writer-director Eran Kolirin has a gentle touch, although the film is too self-consciously sentimental.
In the end, this is a sci-fi zombie movie, folks.
[Director] Bayona draws on everything from Peter Pan to Henry James's The Turn of the Screw, but it has a creepiness that's all its own.
Bee Movie is best viewed as an oddball career move rather than as a successful movie.
Death at a Funeral is a passable example of the British species of comedy. Directed by Frank Oz, it has the requisite amount of knockabout silliness.
Scenes of powerful realism alternate with melodrama.
Compared to a great war zone movie about reporters such as Under Fire, The Hunting Party is thin stuff.
This magnificent documentary about the Apollo missions to the moon contains oodles of original, beautifully remastered NASA footage that has never been seen before.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What Alfred Hitchcock once said about thrillers also applies to Westerns: The stronger the bad guy, the better the film. By that measure, 3:10 to Yuma is excellent.
Quote not available.
At times this indie is as repetitive and self-indulgent as its protagonist, but it captures a bit of the madness of being unrequitedly in love.
Mr. Bean's Holiday is no Monsieur Hulot's Holiday, but preteens especially might enjoy it.
Foster and Howard are both wonderful actors and they try very hard to make this soul stuff work. But the absurdity of the script does them in.
Although the novel was praised for its dead-on accuracy in portraying this high-end world, far too much of the movie is fantastical.
How bad is it? Bad enough -- and yet this source material has such a high creep quotient that, on some level, it still scares.
Everything that happens in this movie is predictable, and yet that's part of its modest charm.
Much of the nattery byplay seems improvised, and the results are very hit and miss -- inspired contretemps alternate with gabfests that seem to go on forever.
Overall the movie coasts on quirkiness.
Stardust has a welcome heft.

Ratner, who has been accurately dubbed a 'fauxteur', does an OK job keeping the action swirling, especially in the finale atop the Eiffel Tower. But there's no particular reason to have kept this franchise going except for commercial expediency.
Too many different stories are vying for attention here, and none of them are very good.
David Cronenberg's Eastern Promises plays like a companion piece to his overrated A History of Violence.
Julie Taymor's flower-powery phantasmagoria is ambitious but ultimately tiresome.
In the Valley of Elah held me despite my many qualms. That's because the subject matter is innately powerful and resists Haggis's pigeonholing. He's latched onto something that's bigger than himself.
Before you recoil in horror at the apparent grossness of yet another Hollywood high concept, you need to know that Lars and the Real Girl is anything but an exploitation film.
A distinct letdown from the 1998 predecessor that helped make Blanchett a star.
Gray loves actors, and it shows.
[A] smart and charming romantic comedy.
Amir Bar-Lev's documentary is fascinating on all kinds of levels: as a movie about the nature of art, the lure and pitfalls of celebrity, and the complicated conundrums of parenting.
Without [Clooney], and without some fine playing from Wilkinson and from Sydney Pollack as the firm's lead partner, Michael Clayton would be glossy claptrap.
The Farrellys' un-PC blend of sex, obscenity, and slapstick comes across as cruel this time because the brothers reduce a very human situation to a series of gross gags.
The Kingdom is ostensibly set in Saudi Arabia but it's really a fantasy action game about winning the war in Iraq.
The fine cast, which includes Jane Alexander, Selma Blair, and Radha Mitchell, is also somewhat underused.
Ang Lee's uneven new film is a bit like a Chinese variant on Paul Verhoeven's The Black Book.
Wes Anderson doesn't make movies like anybody else, which is sometimes a good thing and sometimes not. His latest, The Darjeeling Limited, combines what's best and worst about him.
The blam-blam histrionics devalue the verity.

It's a funny conceit, and the actors -- who include Kathy Baker, Maria Bello, and Hugh Dancy -- are fun to watch. But the entire enterprise ultimately seems designed to turn Austen into a self-help guru.
I wish this movie wasn't so purposefully elegiac and attenuated -- at times it's like a middling Terrence Malick fantasia -- but it's well worth sitting through.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Penn has a real feeling for the stray moments in life that suddenly rush up and overwhelm us with emotion. He also has an eye for beauty in the wilds, of which this film has many. And he's very good with actors.
It's an entertaining pulp pastiche with pretensions.

It may seem perverse to contend that a movie with such a harrowing subject is nevertheless revivifying. But the New Wave of Romanian cinema is the most exciting in the world right now. 4 Months, 3 Weeks, and 2 Days is its latest masterpiece.
Morgan Spurlock is a jokester politico in the Michael Moore vein, and his latest documentary is a low concept posing as a high concept.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Director McDonagh's] seesawing between slapstick and horror comes across as opportunistic because ultimately he cannot place the lives of these men in a credible moral context.
It's so gruesomely relentless that the effect is like watching a slo-mo snuff film.

As gender-segregated experiences go, SATC is preferable to, say, that idiotic beefcake epic 300. The amusing thing about SATC is that it objectifies men in much the same way that most male-oriented movies objectify women.
It's a bewildering mix of very smart and very dumb, but the cast is tiptop.
Powerful, sexually graphic drama.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Crystal Skull is a fun ride, but if we have to wait 19 years for the next one, that's OK by me.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The black comedy Noise may be a one-joke movie but it's a resonant one.
An unstable concoction of political melodrama, film noir, and weepie.
Janssen, who reportedly did her own pool shooting, is [best] served in the scenes with Gulley, which are wrenching in a coolly understated way.
A Norwegian movie that often looks and feels like a resurrected specimen of the French New Wave.
Some of the set pieces are ravishing, more often they're ravishingly clunky.

This angsty Canadian movie directed by Bruce McDonald takes its title all too literally: Every sequence is splintered into multiple split screens, which means that you can follow the dreary, semi-incomprehensible action from many viewpoints at once.
Speed Racer is so hyperfrenetic that, in the end, you wonder if the Wachowskis aren't trying to pull off an elaborate hoax -- a deranged techno fantasia posing as retro-ish family fare.
It was inevitable that an annoying catchphrase would one day become the title for an annoying movie. What Happens in Vegas is not only annoying, it's also incompetent -- a bad mix.
Mamet toys with this existential dilemma but his heart -- or fist -- isn't in it.
This is a bigger and darker Narnia movie and although it didn't leave me famished for the inevitable sequel, it delivers the family-entertainment goods.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It never makes the mistake of condescending to its audience by turning its tykes into overgrown adults. The childhood experience feels emotionally accurate.
Given its subject matter, it's oddly vacuous -- it rarely takes hold emotionally even when its people hit bottom with a resounding thud.
The animation is consistently sporty and there are some choice comic riffs on martial arts movies.
Still, the musical numbers, which constitute a hefty portion of screen time, are thrilling.
Family home movies and photos and archival clips round out the film, which holds its hero-worshiping to fairly tolerable levels.
WALL-E is yet another notch in Pixar's computer-animation belt, and it's one of the better entries, with greater emotional resonance than anything they've done since Finding Nemo.
The film's high proficiency is at the service of a concept that can most accurately be defined as sadomasochistic.
For most of the movie, we feel as trapped as she does, and the lurching narrative seems anything but novelistic.

The first feature film based on the highly popular American Girl book series -- there have already been three made-for-television American Girl movies -- plays out like a sweet-souled Nancy Drew mystery.
Zohan coasts on its premise far more often than it fulfills it. But these days, you take your laughs where you find them. It's a pretty good scattershot comedy.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Get Smart needed to be a lot smarter. And funnier. The movie stands as proof yet again that hit television series do not make for good movies.

A smash-and-slash affair. This probably bodes well for the franchise but ill for those of us who think the world would be a better place with at least one less conflicted comic book antihero glutting the megaplexes.
If you were a fan of David Cronenberg's Crash, you might just be the target audience for Quid Pro Quo, a perverse psychological drama about able-bodied people who yearn to become disabled.
A supremely cranky and lyrical feat.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's also a bit sneaky of Shyamalan to set us up for a paranoid 9/11 thriller and then go all Greenpeace on us. He's trying to be socially conscious but he doesn't have the reformist's temperament. He has the temperament of a self-infatuated messiah.
Mongol is a throwback to a more respectable tradition. The largeness of its scope arises naturally from the material, not the budget. The movie earns its stature.
The film's parallels between Mohmed's travails and the Iraq war are forced, but overall this is a fascinating odyssey that never plays out in ways you would expect.
What links all these characters is Myers's gift for antic, elfin burlesque. He's like a second-best Peter Sellers.
Patrick Dempsey goes into charm overload in Made of Honor, to no avail.

When Iron Man is zooming above bejewelled southern California, I expected a thundering lyricism but instead settled for some routine CGI stunts. I suppose it's asking too much for a great actor to be matched up with a great director.
[Director Lelouch] doesn't really move much beyond his usual glib panache here, but the plot is intriguing and so are the actors.
The cast is first-rate but nothing goes very far in this film.
It's fortunate that Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day stars Frances McDormand and Amy Adams. Actors' showcases are only worthwhile if the actors are worth watching.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Bank Job is nothing more than an efficient time-killer with the added bonus of being based on a real misadventure. But, unlike its benighted cast of characters, it gets the job done without a hitch.
It made me yearn to see Caveman again. At least that was intentionally funny.
Worth seeing for the expert archival selections, but a decidedly mixed bag for anyone familiar, or unfamiliar, with the times.
This half-baked fairy tale always seems to be on the verge of becoming charming but despite a good cast it never quite succeeds.
It's so funny and good-natured that I can't imagine anybody not smiling through it. Not even a Grinch.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A richly appointed period piece, it features kingly tantrums, mistresses, bodices, roaring fireplaces, incest, and mutton. It also features sharply enunciated, period-perfect dialogue in which nary a contraction can be heard.
The moral dilemmas posed by this operation are dramatically rendered, and without once resorting to cant.
Yelchin gives Charlie a fresh-faced naiveté that raises the question: Is he a do-gooder or a villain? And do you care?
Writer-director Cao Hamburger works well with child actors and has a spare, unforced style.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Definitely, Maybe isn't terrible exactly, but it's bland, and in some ways that's worse. It's a romance posing as a detective story in which the solution is obvious and not worth the fuss.
Jumper has so many loose ends that it almost cries out for a sequel. This, of course, is intentional. I would say the filmmakers are being a tad optimistic.
Director Mark Waters does a fine job meshing the fantastical with the quotidian.
Ferrell is pretty much the whole show.

Despite its deficiencies, and the inadequate screen time allotted to Theron (who's quite good), Sleepwalking has a core of feeling. It's about a do-gooder who, lacking all skills for it, does good anyway. His emotional odyssey has real poignancy.
The sentimentality quotient for this film is set too high.
Does anybody seriously believe that mother and son will not reunite in the end? It's only a question of how, not if.
At this late date there is little that is factually revelatory about his film, but as a human document of what people are capable of in wartime, it's indispensable.
The pregnancy-movie craze shows no signs of abating, but not all bellies are created equal. Baby Mama is a disservice to Tina Fey, who is at her best playing characters who are whip-smart.
As is so often the case with sequels, this one feels like a retread, albeit on a bigger scale.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director Vadim Perelman is big on slo-mo lyrical effects and confusing time shifts, making the movie unnecessarily arty and detracting from what could have been a searing psychological study.

Here's the thing about Pacino: He's often at his most entertaining when he's chewing the scenery.... Watching a great actor raise the roof is often more enjoyable than watching an OK actor deliver the goods.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall is, ultimately, forgettable, but for most of the way it's a pleasant little vacation of a movie.
Don't be fooled by the presence of Meryl Streep in the cast. This glum, inert psychological drama features little of her presence - and could have used much more.
Makes you want to go out and join a chorus -- whatever your age may be.
McCarthy is so careful not to take a political stand that his film seems neutered by good intentions. In the spirit of squishy humanism, he soft-pedals a hard-hitting topic.
Quaid and Church are funny, but too much of this film is not half as smart as it thinks it is.
Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien knows how to cast a spell of loneliness.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The disappointment is that, unlike The Last Waltz, which got inside the skins of The Band and was clearly a deeply personal work, Shine A Light is essentially just an expertly made concert film. But what a concert!
The Hong Kong director Wong Kar Wai has an undeservedly high reputation as a master stylist. He's more like a master window dresser.

Even in a middling comedy such as this one, which he also directed, he's alarmingly ardent. Clooney is relying on the tremendous audience rapport he's built up over the years, and he's right to do so.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Several good actors turn up to no particular effect -- including Ray Winstone as Finn's surly mentor, and Donald Sutherland as a mega-yacht-owning billionaire.
Although this is Ferguson's first feature -- he paid for it himself -- it's a masterfully assured piece of filmmaking.
It's a formulaic, overacted piece of work that rarely delves deep.
Here, as in that other new-style spy movie Casino Royale, everything is hard and fast and brutal and, above all, straight-faced. No throwaway lines, no puns.

The First French Army, composed mostly of 130,000 North Africans, were referred to contemptuously by the French as indigènes -- natives. Their bravery in wartime has never, until now, been adequately described in a movie.
If you thought that the Buena Vista Social Club was all that needed to be said about Cuban music, now there's East of Havana, which is about the Cuba rap scene.
Grbavica: The Land of My Dreams is written and directed by Jasmila Zbanic in a stripped-down style that carries cumulative force.
Without Cooper's performance, Breach would have been a good, workmanlike thriller. His presence lifts it to a whole new level.
Blanchett has also recently appeared in The Good German and Babel, but this represents far and away her best work.
Quote not available.
It makes you want to cover your eyes and clutch your ears.
If writer-director Marc Lawrence had stuck with Alex's faded glory, Music and Lyrics could have been terrific. It could have been about something.
The director is fortunate to have cast actors who fully embody their roles.
Even more so than with the other Lecter movies, this prequel you should plan on seeing after you've eaten dinner. Better yet, skip the movie altogether and have dessert.
Seraphim Falls isn't completely without interest, particularly for those of us who still like Westerns and bemoan their demise almost as much as we bemoan the demise of the movie musical.

Annabelle Gurwitch was fired from a play by Woody Allen and has been making something of a cottage industry out of the experience ever since. Having written a book about being fired, she has now made a documentary as well, and it's something of a mess.
Wince-inducing.

Pan's Labyrinth resembles a cross between Alice in Wonderland and H.P. Lovecraft, with some Buñuel thrown in for good measure. It's a tribute to -- as well as a prime example of -- the disturbing power of imagination.
Burton is extraordinary in one of his rare good movie roles and O'Toole is regally madcap and larger than life.
The Italian is not so much about present-day Russia as it is an upbeat fable of what [director Andrei] Kravchuk envisions as its future. It's a wish-fulfillment fantasy posing as hard-edged realism.

Some movies are so flagrantly awful that they achieve classic status. To this rarefied company we must now add The Astronaut Farmer, a nut brain fable that is all the more perversely enjoyable for being seriously intended.

A modestly enjoyable comedy set in the 1980s about a working-class student from Essex who goes to Bristol University and scrambles to get on the team for the British television quiz show University Challenge.
The interaction between soldiers and captives becomes a microcosm for an entire culture. It's a wisp of a movie but it has stayed with me longer than much supposedly weightier fare.
The Last Mimzy, it should be said, is exceedingly mild whimsy. It also has a story that no doubt will be too diffuse for small children -- or the big adults who accompany them.
[James] Garner is good, and so is Brian Dennehy as a crusty ranch owner; Abigail Breslin, playing a leukemia patient, demonstrates that she was not a one-note wonder in Little Miss Sunshine.
The 1994 Rwandan genocide is once again the subject of a movie. Even more so than its forerunner Hotel Rwanda, Beyond the Gates is unsparing in its depiction of that terrible time.
Loach has a long and honored career as a political filmmaker, and The Wind that Shakes the Barley is more accessible -- i.e. conventional -- than most of his other films.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: May I suggest that it's time to declare a moratorium on movies about time?
[Director Michael Apted] has an unfortunate penchant for bland stateliness, and never more so than in Amazing Grace.

The Namesake takes in a lot of territory, and at times is too diffuse, too attenuated. But the actors are so expressive that they provide their own continuity. They transport us to a realm of pure feeling.

Scurlock's filmmaking style leans more heavily on woebegone personal testimony than facts and figures, but politicians willing to go up against the credit industry's lobbyists would be well advised to take a look.

Just about everything in this pea-brained epic is overscaled and overwrought -- it's a cartoon trying to be a towering triptych. The dissonance between the film's heroic ambitions and its grindingly coarse treatment is rather amusing.
The doggedness of the pursuit, the painstaking accumulation of clues, has its own inherent drama.
Even Chevy Chase wouldn't be caught dead doing this stuff.

[Heather Graham] needs something to counteract her wholesomeness. In Gray Matters -- her name is Gray, get it? -- what you see is what you get. The fact that her character 'discovers' she is gay is as unbelievable as it is contrived.
Maybe Jackson should avoid any more movies with 'snake' in the title.
A cross between Godzilla and Jaws, it manages to be both truly scary and truly funny -- sometimes all at once.
Pride is a fairly good example of the genre.
[Alberto Sordi has] a marvelous performance in a marvelous movie, one that sneaks up on you while you're watching it.
As both historical document and human document, this 180-minute epic is infinitely valuable.
movie_title: Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Trial 1963-1965 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a rather lifeless re-telling of the Nativity, with greeting-card imagery and stiff performances.
It's borderline unwatchable.
I can understand [Black] wanting to make King Kong, but Nacho Libre was a dismal affair and Tenacious D isn't much better.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bennett captures the racy, joshing, embattled atmosphere inside a British boarding school better than anybody has done since Terence Rattigan's The Browning Version.
What gives the film its jolt of urgency is its New Orleans setting. Déjà Vu is the first major movie to be shot there since the city's devastation.
Arbus's life has been put through the fantasy blender.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A great big puzzle movie that even Lynch appears not to have figured out.
Everyone in this film is powerful.
Viewers expecting a blistering attack on the fast-food business, or an Altmanesque panorama, will be disappointed, but it's a sensitive and humane piece of work.
Casino Royale unveils Daniel Craig as the new James Bond and, excepting Sean Connery, he's the best.
The lush glimmer of the scenery is so eye-catching that it's easy to sit back and experience A Good Year as a kind of tony travelogue.
Movies with terrific ideas are a rare commodity in Hollywood. The idea behind Stranger Than Fiction is the kind of Charlie Kaufmanesque conceit that sounds a lot better than the way it's played out.
Borat is the funniest comedy I've seen since I don't know when.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is both child-friendly and, in its frequent jokes and topical references, adult-friendly, too. What it lacks is the heart to make it really stick in the imagination.
Marilyn may not rate an Oscar nomination, but O'Hara certainly does.
Engaging but clichéd inspirational drama set during the time of the 1992 race riots in Los Angeles. On some level, just about any movie featuring never-say-die teachers is effective.
Rehab comes not a moment too soon.
Gibson is never content to show us just one or two decapitated heads bouncing down the steps of a temple when he can show us eight or nine.
Although Zellweger strains a bit too hard at being eccentric, [Ewan] McGregor is entrancingly valorous playing opposite her.

At times the film is so supercharged that it glosses over the story's thematic richness and turns into a very high-grade action picture. But if that's the worst thing you can say about a movie, you're doing all right.
An "American Idol" rejectee with no prior screen experience, [Jennifer Hudson's] presence in this film is itself the stuff that musical dreams are made of.
In its emotional simplicity and straightforward narrative punch, Letters also harks back to what was best about those war movies.
Zhang Yimou's latest extravaganza is about palace intrigue during the Tan Dynasty, and it's exhaustingly action-packed.
The Good Shepherd does occasionally strike the right, creepy note.
With a less camera-friendly duo, this movie could have been a real dud. Even so, it's nothing much. It does have the great virtue of being only 82 minutes long, though.
It's a powerful subject, but director McG and screenwriter Jamie Linden haul out every cliché in the playbook.
Decorous to a fault, in the manner of middling Eric Rohmer talkfests, it's a film that could use some shaking up.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: O'Toole has such a one-of-a-kind face that at times the director, Roger Michell, is content just to have his camera gaze upon it. That puts a burden on O'Toole, who cannot, and doesn't care to, hide the ravages of time.
The Good German is a prime example of a movie made by highly skilled and intelligent filmmakers that nevertheless seems misguided from the get-go.
Playing a cantankerous, beer-swigging human wreck of a man for the umpteenth time, Nolte is very good but very familiar.
Sappy, sugary, star-driven, The Holiday is a confection right off the Hollywood assembly line.
Much more so than those earlier films, Blood Diamond freely combines political grandstanding with action-adventure heroics.
It's almost impossible to watch this movie and not, on some level beyond reason, succumb. The Pursuit of Happyness is an expert piece of calculation: a male weepie engineered for the whole family.

[Director Scott] Frank wrote the film adaptations of Elmore Leonard's Out of Sight and Get Shorty, and at times he seems to be trying for a similar tough-tender tone. But the material here is more fragile than Leonard's, more touchy-feely.
Director Alexandra Lipsitz doesn't do much more than chronicle the noise, but it's intermittently fun stuff.
Killer of Sheep was declared a national treasure in 1990 by the Library of Congress. I agree.
A dreary mood romance that flashes back and forth between present day and 50 years ago.
Easily the best in the series since the first one.
In sequence after sequence, we are presented with visual set pieces that far exceed the imaginativeness of most live-action dramatic fare.

On so many levels, A Mighty Heart is almost as excruciating to write about as it is to watch. It has many of the virtues of a first-rate political thriller, and yet who can think of it in those terms?
A pleasantly disposable romantic comedy.
It has its amusements.
It may incite lawmakers in a position to help to trumpet their faux proletarian credentials.
If there is one thing that kills comedy, it's sanctimoniousness.
Dan Klores's astonishing film is about a subject so bizarre it could only work as a documentary -- as a drama, it would be dismissed as being too far-fetched.
So tepid that even Nancy Drew loyalists may take a pass on any further cinematic adventures.
As summer franchise superhero flicks go, it's tolerable.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing about this movie settles into normalcy. It's a celebration, a memorial, a tease, a death knell.
Complexly intriguing.
Equating an artist's life with her art is often a dubious dramatic ploy, but it makes sense in La Vie En Rose because the content of Piaf's life and the power of her singing are all of a piece.

What rescues Eagle vs. Shark is its focus on Lily. Although Horsley overdoes the winsomeness, she is genuinely appealing. Love erases Lily's geekiness and in its place stands an attractive young woman.

The most enjoyable thing about the Ocean's movies is that nobody involved seems to take them seriously. The star wattage is immense but the stars themselves are refreshingly self-deprecating, almost satirically so.
It's all a lot closer to melodrama than drama, but Thalbach is a dynamo.

What keeps Transformers watchable is LaBeouf and the computerized effects, which are often startling. When Sam's Camaro muscles up into the Bumblebee bot, it's like watching every boy's fantasy of his first pair of wheels.
Laura Morante proves once again that she is one of the most intelligent and attractive actresses in the world.
The best reason to see this documentary is for the stunning shots of polar bears and walruses in the Arctic Circle. If the filmmakers had just left it at that, they would have accomplished a lot.

No Reservations is diverting because of all the gleaming food on display. For those of us who can't stand the heat and so stay out of the kitchen, the intricate preparation of quail with truffle sauce is a wonder to behold.
The movie is best when it just riffs on our compacted memories of the past 18 years of episodes. Fortunately, that's most of the time.
Hairspray is a feel-good musical that, for a change, actually makes you feel good.
Portman is saddled with the worst role. Ines spends much of her screen time acting blighted and deranged, a condition not improved by Portman's penchant for stage theatrics.
I have rarely seen a movie with less self-knowledge than License to Wed, an awful comedy made ever so slightly fascinating because of its dual personality.
Danny Boyle gets some tension going, and, as the crew members are eliminated one by one, a cosmic despair sets in.

Don Cheadle, along with Taraji P. Henson, act up a storm in this biopic about Petey Greene, a 1960s-era deejay who shook up the airwaves with his streetwise rant. Their performances deserve a better film.
The back-and-forth between the performers is tensely choreographed, and Buscemi does a good job opening up the action, which mostly takes place in a Manhattan loft.
French filmmakers have often been at odds with the Hollywood juggernaut. With My Best Friend, Leconte seems to be throwing up his hands. If you can't beat them, join them.
Yates, especially given the sinister subject matter on hand, does a rather workmanlike job of traffic-managing the action. But some of the magic effects are indeed magical.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

It was co-written by the authors of "Anaconda 2" and the director of "Hitch" and the Drew Barrymore version of the Amy Fisher story and even by those less-than-robust standards, they are playing well below their respective high-water marks
A smart and incisive look at contemporary relationships that avoids all the cliches that one might expect to find
It may be a Tarantino knock-off in the end but it is one of the most entertaining Tarantino knock-offs that I can recall seeing in recent memory.
"Taxi to the Dark Side" takes a vast and potentially confusing subject and discovers the simple truths that have been largely obscured in a mass of details, sloppy reporting and general disinterest.

Writer-director Christian Mungiu has made the choice to let the material play out in a calm and even-handed manner in the hopes that the despair and barely-contained anger that he is trying to convey will come through without having to underline them.
The irony about all the soullessness on display in terms of the music and the merchandising is the film does do a good job of deploying its enormously likable central asset, Miley Cyrus.
movie_title: Hannah Montana: One in a Million (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If Burt Reynolds supposedly punched PT Anderson in the nose for the crime of putting him in Boogie Nights, God only knows what he did to Uwe Boll for putting him in Dungeon Siege.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A God-awful film that seems to suggest that terminal cancer can be a blast as long as you have access to billions of dollars, a green-screen machine and a philosophical narrator offering homespun bits of wisdom at every turn.
A film so utterly misbegotten that it almost makes Alien Vs. Predator: Requiem look competent by comparison.

This is a film in which the name "Bob Dylan" is never uttered once and yet it still comes closer to getting to the bottom of the man, his music and his myths than anything that I can recall reading or seeing.

This may not be the single dumbest movie of the year but, to paraphrase Tommy Lee Jones in No Country For Old Men (a film as good as this one is bad), it will do until the dumbest one finally arrives.
It is one of the rare British period literary adaptations that feels like a fresh and vital story instead of a museum piece
A cheerfully bizarre delight for anyone open to its decidedly off-beat charms.
It not only more than lives up to all of the advanced hype, it is actually even better than the advanced word has been suggesting.
Even as an incredibly expensive hunk of eye candy, the film comes up surprisingly short.
While much of "Awake" simply doesn't work, there are just enough things on display that do to make you wish that someone had taken the time to elaborate on them
It quickly becomes obvious that instead of finding a fresh angle of approach, the filmmakers have simply given us yet another fish-out-of-water fantasy a la "Splash."
Come back, "Eragon"--all is forgiven!

There have many films in the last year or so that have dealt with the war in Iraq, but I can't recall one that infuriated me as much as this smugly insufferable soap opera that uses the conflict as an excuse to offer up 90 minutes of muddled mawkishness
I suspect that it will be registered as one of those fascinating follies that retains its mystique and allure long after the memory of the more successful films of the season has faded into nothing.
An often-hilarious political satire that tells a story so bizarre and unlikely that it comes as no surprise to discover that most of it is indeed true
Burton's work here is strong and self-assured and never allows the lavish production design to dominate the storytelling.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It may be utter nonsense from start to finish but at a time when your moviegoing choices are limited to deeply serious Oscar bait and silly family froth, its appearance comes as a raunchy relief.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It feels like the kind of project that Meg Ryan would have turned down back in the 90's for being just a little too hackneyed and cliched for its own good.
It makes Alien Vs. Predator look like Alien or Predator by comparison.
A true American epic in every sense of the word -- the kind of film that people will be analyzing and admiring for as long as people will continue to do such things.
"The Spiderwick Chronicles" is a modest and reasonably charming example of a genre that isn't exactly renowned for modesty or charm.
[A film] that is likely to outrage and provoke anyone who comes into contact with it.
It plays exactly like a trailer that has been stretched out to 88 minutes%u2013all money shots with no story or engaging characters to tie them together

A brainless piece of product that is so utterly devoid of anything not concerned with the idea of separating 12-year-olds from their allowance that it makes the Hannah Montana infomercial/movie seem like "There Will Be Blood" by comparison

The characters are so one-note and unlikable that most viewers will find themselves looking forward to their grisly demises because it means that they won't be annoying us anymore.
"Leatherheads" is a profoundly unprofound film that really doesn't have anything on its mind other than to give audiences a couple of hours of giggly fun.
Outside of a brief clip from "Can't Hardly Wait," there is absolutely nothing in "Prom Night" that is even remotely scary.

The James Ellroy that I know and admire wouldn't concoct a storyline that is so crashingly obvious that virtually every member of the audience will have sussed out who is at the bottom of the conspiracy at least an hour before it finally dawns on our hero

"Priceless" is a film that appears to have been made to answer the question "How far can a movie get along with nothing going for it but the irrepressible charm of Audrey Tautou?" The answer, it turns out, is "pretty far."

A slick, soulless nightmare of a film with the moral center of a porno flick and a central character so shallow, loathsome and uninteresting that you keep hoping that the guys from "Funny Games" will show up and give him exactly what he deserves.

Finally, the martial arts genre gets its own version of "City Heat."

movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: "My Blueberry Nights" is perhaps the most deliriously entertaining thing that Wong has ever made, at least since the equally rapturous "Chungking Express."
This is the film that should have been called "Coma"

A slightly-better-than-average popcorn epic featuring a performance from Downey that is so funny and inventive and entertaining that he pretty much winds up carrying the entire movie on his shoulders.

The good news about "Superhero Movie" is that it is better than either of the "Fantastic Four" movies. The bad news is that it isn't that much better.
It is essentially a one-joke premise and while it might have played beautifully as a 30-minute short subject, there just isn't enough to it to sustain itself as a 90-minute feature.
Lichtenstein has a lot of ambitious ideas for his debut film but lacks the skills to pull any of them off

It starts off strong but quickly becomes so contrived and repetitive that by the time it finally lumbers to its deeply unsatisfying and ludicrously melodramatic finale, you feel like an idiot for having wasted your time watching it
Smug, painfully unoriginal and about as hip and edgy as a trip to Sears.

I don't want to come down too hard on "The Signal" because while I don't think that it ultimately works in the end, it is far more ambitious in both concept and execution than the majority of contemporary American horror efforts

When the executioner finally makes his appearance at the end, it will probably inspire the kind of delirious relief and good cheer from audiences that is usually only experienced when Christopher Walken makes an unexpected cameo

A bit of a mess but it is such an energetic and ambitious mess that it winds up capturing the energy and feel of its subject better than a more staid approach to the material possibly could have achieved.

Some viewers may find its self-conscious eccentricities to be somehow charming but if you put this film in a contest against other contemporary fairy tales, it wouldn't come close to winning%u2013not even by a nose.
This may well be the first prehistoric epic in which the liberal deployment of such words as "oog," "agh" and "uck" would have actually improved the screenplay considerably.
It does have its charms and while I can't entirely recommend it, I am not exactly sorry that I saw it.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating meditation on the commercialization of violence in popular culture that will shock even the most jaded moviegoers into contemplating what they look for in mass entertainment.

movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

A strangely exhilarating and undeniably powerful work of American cinema that is sure to go down as one of the very best films of the year.
Outside of a couple of moments of self-conscious shock humor, the most surprising thing about the film is how square it really is.

To describe it as lazy hackwork would be an insult to the phrase "lazy hackwork."
The kind of movie that is far more interesting and edifying to read about and discuss than it is to actually sit through.

The same old stuff served in an admittedly stylish manner.

The end result is a shrill and silly misfire that comes across like an exceptionally expensive piece of television%u2013either a sitcom or a Lifetime Original Movie%u2013than a real movie.
An enormously disappointing waste of time and talent that even the most forgiving of genre buffs will find almost impossible to sit through without squirming in their seats out of sheer boredom.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

Inscrutable and Insufferable

The film is too gauche to work as a real musical and too flat to work as camp.

135 minutes of noisy, infantile and shockingly boring mind rot that will inspire only partial epilepsy in viewers whose ages remain in the single digits and complete ennui in those who have passed the big 1-0.

By the prickling of my thumbs/Something crappy this way comes

A film that works as a thrilling adventure as exciting and visceral as any put on the screen in recent memory and as an intimate character piece about an ordinary man whose extraordinary courage allows him to persevere against seemingly insurmountable odd

Van Gogh has now received the most profound posthumous tribute that the American film industry could possibly bestow with this tepid and only fitfully interesting remake of his own 2003 feature of the same name.

"Blade Runner" is no mere museum piece%u2013it continues to live and breathe in a manner unlike the vast majority of contemporary films, regardless of genre, and this is why it continues to resonate just as strongly as it did back in 1982.

A well-made and reasonably exciting work filled with juicy performances, exciting set-pieces and a slick visual style, but there is very little on display here that we haven't already seen before in one form or another.

A film that is less a fully developed portrait of its subject than it is a rough snapshot that conveys the immediacy of the times in a more gripping manner than most of the current crop of fictional films on the subject.

Amazingly, it is even worse than it looks.
So egregiously awful that it not only gives a bad name to parody movies, it gives bad names to each of the individual letters used to form the words "parody movies."

Stridently annoying.

if you do go and see this film, I would urge you to stop off at your local video store on the way home in order to rent "My Dog Skip" and see what a movie of this type looks like when it is done well.

a multicultural masterwork that is sure to delight viewers of all ages

This is a film that, much like its subject, is a flawed and fascinating work whose ultimate power is derived less from the ideas of the man at its center than by his intense charisma, supplied here by an amazing central performance from Benicio del Toro.

One of the most ruthlessly efficient and sheerly entertaining hardcore action films to come along in a long time.

A brilliant portrait of post-adolescent angst that looks and feels like the great film that John Hughes never quite got around to making

The fight choreography in "Hannah Montana" is infinitely better.

movie_review_blurb: The film marks Michael Keaton's directorial debut and if this film accomplishes anything at all, its relative failure may finally inspire him to return to the day job from which he has been missing for far too long.

A visually stunning family-oriented fantasy that will simultaneously enchant kids and creep out parents.

To describe the film as this generation's "Wired" hardly begins to scratch the surface. This is a movie so bad that the people who actually made "Wired" can actually look down upon it without coming across as hypocritical.

a.k.a "Black Belt Norah Jones"
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

A pleasant variation on a very familiar theme

movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A mesmerizing new documentary that contains some of the most stunning, unlikely and unforgettable moments that Herzog has ever given us and by definition, that means that they are some of the most stunning, unlikely and unforgettable moments ever seen.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A great work of contemporary cinema and easily the most artistically significant film ever made to ever inspire its own fast-food pizza tie-in.

movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In the ten years since the first film and six years since the ending of the series, couldn't they have come up with something more interesting than a plot that suggests what "They Saved Hitler's Brain" might have been like in the hands of Andy Milligan?
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It may not be the most sophisticated film around but every once in a while, you need an unabashedly juvenile goof to sort of clear the pipes and this one gets the job done.

In trying to wrestle the story into a workable running time, the film has taken a greatest hits approach to the material that recreates the best-known moments but which lacks all of the nuance and detail of either the book or the miniseries.

You get the sense that it has been written both by and for ADD-afflicted children who have seen way too many movies and who are determined to simply repeat their favorite parts from them, regardless of whether or not they make any sense.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It almost manages to restore (at least temporarily) one's faith in both the democratic process and Kevin Costner's career.

A stoner film that actually lives up to all the buzz, both in the press and in the audience.

movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: "Finding Amanda" is little more than what "Hardcore" might have been like if it had been rewritten by the author of a dirty joke book--an idea that, come to think of it, is actually more amusing than anything on display here.
Two hours of solid and occasionally spectacular entertainment that doesn't trash any fondly-held childhood memories along the way.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Imagine what "Catch-22" might have been like if it had been written by that creepy grade-school classmate of yours who was always talking about how cool it would be to stick a cherry bomb under that dead squirrel he found on the side of the road
143 minutes of unbearably shallow characters, numerous extraneous plot threads in lieu of a central storyline and more product placements than in the "Cannonball Run" saga entire.

movie_review_blurb: The film is so restrained and deadpan that it barely seems alive

I have read reviews from seemingly sensible critics who have found this one to be equally amusing, which would indicate that they are all on some wavelength that I am as yet not privy to or that I need to recalibrate my conception of the word "sensible."

A thudding dull and dunderheaded piece of product that is generally uninteresting to look at, frequently painful to listen to and a constant insult to all the things that Ang Lee accomplished in his take on the material.

However, while it may not be particularly original or inspired, it does contain the one ingredient that has been largely missing from most American comedies of late--actual laughs--and it provides enough of those to make it worth a look.
As horrible, wretched, infantile, disgusting and flat-out lousy as "The Love Guru" is, that is how wonderful "WALL*E" is.
One of the cheerfully insane, visually extraordinary and compulsively entertaining action blockbusters to emerge from Hollywood in a long, long time.

The film lacks the urgency and, ironically, the intelligence required for something along these lines to succeed.
A loud, depressing and confusing would-be franchise-starter that is just as murky, corrupt and exhausted as the post-apocalyptic world that it depicts.

This is not just Demme's most thematically, emotionally and narratively ambitious project since the masterpiece that was "Something Wild," it may well be the best thing that he has done since that film.

Forget inside baseball, this film comes across more like inside whiffleball than anything else--a simulacrum that looks sort of like the real thing but which never runs the risk of hitting as hard as the real thing.

[Gibney] is never quite able to get beyond the familiar in order to give viewers a new and penetrating look at the subject of Thompson and his work.

One of the best films of 2008 and one of the finest films to date from a man commonly regarded as one of the world's greatest filmmakers.

So ugly, unpleasant and devoid of laughs that the notion of releasing a film with such a title on the third anniversary of Hurricane Katrina is actually one of the least offensive things about it.

In the end. "Burn After Reading" is a film that is essentially about nothing much at all but it goes about achieving that nothing in such audaciously funny ways that it turns out to be something after all.

There is such a palpable lack of enthusiasm from the two stars that it feels at times as if the film has been entirely crafted out of rehearsal footage of them going through the material at quarter-speed in order to save their energy for the actual take.
A tiresome and fairly hateful mess that wants to raise hackles but only succeeds in coming across like a Todd Solondz film sans the wit, whimsy and empathy.

Where is Dutch Schultz and his meat fork when you need them?
two hours of absolute nonsense that is easily the noisiest action film to come around the pike since "Transformers" and quite possibly the dumbest one to boot.

[The filmmakers] tackle the familiar material with such gleeful zest, thanks in no small part to an extremely game cast, that I didn't mind that there wasn't anything on display that I hadn't already before in one form or another.

Fails on any number of cinematic levels.

A film so singularly lousy that it almost makes the similarly crappy 2002 original look competent by comparison.

One of the most inept, laugh-free comedies in recent memory.

Genuinely awful.
I wish that director/co-writer Todd Phillips...could have come up with something a little smarter than this nonsense.

The thing that makes David Mamet's 'Spartan' so thrilling and exciting to watch is not the story...but the specific way that he has chosen to tell the story.
Brilliant, an endlessly clever, funny and strangely moving story that will leave viewers with a warm heart and smoke curling out of their ears.

movie_review_blurb: The story is, as you can tell, preposterous from the get-go...

Deeply offensive, staggeringly unfunny, pretentious and, at 140 minutes, about 135 minutes too long...

It is not a total failure by any means but, unlike its title character, it proves itself to be far to willing to settle and move on instead of trying to do something riskier and more potentially rewarding.
The Disaster Artist misses its shot at greatness but it is still an enormously entertaining work that serves as a celebration of the artistic process.
It is the best and most innovative Star Wars film to come along in a long time and you would think that this would inspire celebration in the streets among longtime fans of the franchise.
Michael Caine has at long last managed to appear in a movie with the word "island" in the title that is even worse than "The Island."
In the effort to top what has gone before, the film ignores the quieter elements that have always been just as important to the series as whole.
The script is so bad -- so desperately unfunny, painfully mawkish and awkwardly contrived -- that not even the three stars... can do much of anything with it.

The problem with the film is that it never quite finds that final spark of inspiration that might have made it worth seeing, let alone producing in the first place, and it is further hampered by some clunkiness in the storytelling department.
"Nina Forever" subverts audience expectations at every turn and develops the kind of genuine emotional power that keeps it from being just another gory goof.
A horrible and wildly unnecessary follow-up that might actually be worse than its predecessor.
You may be taken aback by just how good it really is.
Despite that late inning stumble, Road Games still provides enough suspense, thrills and dark humor to leave genre buffs more than satisfied.
As things progress, however, director Roar Uthaug allows his film to succumb to the same flaws that have undone many an American disaster film.
"Criminal" is the kind of dunderheaded enterprise that leaves viewers reeling from the idiocies they have just endured, wondering how something like that could possibly get made in the first place.
"The Measure of a Man" may be a hard film to watch at times, but with Lindon's great performance at its center, it is one from which you cannot look away.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You will be hard-pressed to remember anything about it even only a few minutes after watching it, which should come as a relief to everyone involved with its production.
A film so awful that if one were to put up a list of the great films celebrating motherhood, it would rank considerably lower than the Gus van Sant version of "Psycho."
There are times when it feels as if the producers challenged themselves to see how little it needed and still meet the legal definition of a movie.
While the visual presentation of "The Dresser" may be somewhat lacking in sparks, it more than makes up for that with the undeniably fiery and entertaining turns from both Hopkins and McKellen.
A thoroughly mediocre movie that is never as amusing as it should be.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Those looking for a story equal to Cranston's contributions to it are liable to come away from it feeling slightly disappointed.
Little more than an extended version of the kind of political screeds that can be found online with only a minimum of effort, this is just a terrible movie.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part, though, the film is just a tired tread through the usual elements.
A strong, smart and moving end-of-the-world drama that is further bolstered by strong performances from co-stars Ellen Page and Evan Rachel Wood.
The 3-D conversion is so murky that there are long stretches where it is almost impossible to discern what is going on up on the screen.
While fans of the series may get something out of the sequel, there is nothing on display that could possibly sway naysayers.

Jude gets strong performances from his three leads and, with the help of cinematographer Marius Panduru, has created an uncommonly beautiful film ... that at times evokes the simple beauties of classic Westerns.
The only thing about it worth remembering is that it was the last film made by wrestler-turned-actor Roddy Piper before his death last year.

What this film may lack in terms of visual flamboyance, it more than makes up for in telling its simple and direct story with a raw, emotional power that doesn't need lavish spectacle in order to get its point across.
Those with stronger constitutions will find it to be an excursion to the cinematic dark side that is a million times removed from such recent genre gibberish as "Unfriended" or "The Gallows."
A wildly entertaining work, one that manages to be simultaneously funny, touching, slightly unnerving and undeniably sexy to behold, regardless of where your predilections may lie.

An occasionally strange, occasionally brutal and occasionally lovely work that goes up on the shelf with "The Ocean of Helena Lee" and "Girlhood" as one of the more impressive coming-of-age tales of recent times.
Whenever one of the stories begins to generate any real head of steam, viewers are jerked into another one and the whole process starts over again.

Those who demand that their films offer up some kind of conventional narrative structure will no doubt throw up their hands and leave early on in the proceedings. Those that stick it out, however, will be rewarded with one delight after another.
Visually ravishing and formally graceful ...
The sixth time is not the charm with this load of hooey that tries to make up for its lack of legitimate scares or basic narrative clarity by adding the alleged miracle of 3-D into the mix.
A deeply irritating horror-comedy that might have worked as a "Funny or Die" short but which is pretty much DOA as a feature-length concern.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Such a borderline unendurable exercise in vapid self-indulgence that it almost feels like an exceptionally straight-faced parody of empty-headed star vehicles.

The film will satisfy younger viewers, I suppose, but unless your kids are especially gaga over dinosaurs, my guess is that even they will recognize that it is lacking a certain something that separates the great films from the ordinary ones.
Creed is superior popular entertainment that shows that a mass audience can be electrified by a film that does not rely on elaborate set-pieces or complicated special effects.
A cheerfully silly and goofily gory homage to 80's-era cheapo action films whose boxes always promised more than they ever came close to delivering.
Although there are some amusing moments here and there and a couple of nicely effective scary bits, it is never quite as darkly funny nor as frightening as it would like to be ...
As is the case with all films of this type, your mileage will vary depending on the number of stories that you wind up liking.

Pixar has returned with their fifteenth feature, Inside Out, and I am happy... to inform you that they have evidently regained their magic touch and then some. Not only is it their best movie in years, it is one of their best period.

25 years later, we have now been blessed a "Point Break" remake that is completely lacking in any of the visceral thrills or apparent charisma of the original and which could not be duller if it tried.
There is a good and interesting movie out there to be made about the tragic events at Benghazi and the political aftermath but "13 Hours" is definitely not it.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Colossal is one of those movies that is so audacious in so many ways that most viewers will find themselves needing to see it twice.

This is an extraordinary portrait of a complicated and contradictory man and regardless of your previously held views towards him, it is complex and thoughtful enough to force you to reconsider and reshape them as a result.
Gans and Co. have given us a sumptuous and highly watchable take on the story that is a more than worthy work in its own right.
movie_title: Beauty And The Beast (La belle et la bête) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You can practically feel it straining to become a classic of the genre but in the end, it feels more like Miller's Crossing cosplay than anything else.
Easily one of the very best of 2016.

It is so completely demented in so many ways that it beggars belief that it could have made its journey from the page to big screen without anyone in a position of power along the way trying to shut the whole thing down.

A hugely entertaining film in which all of the elements fall into place so seamlessly that it can't help but make the vast majority of recent would-be blockbusters look even lamer than they already do.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Park] has taken what could have been an ordinary and genteel costume drama and transformed it into an electrifying work that is in equal parts smart, bizarre, darkly funny, violent, powerfully acted and genuinely erotic.
The visual pleasures hardly begin to compensate for the inescapable fact that the movie as a whole is a leaden and pretentious trainwreck of a creation that is equal parts boring and bewildering.

An absurdly over-scaled and wildly implausible drama that misses the mark so often that most people will likely come out of it... befuddled as they desperately try to understand what the point of the whole endeavor was in the first place.
The Shack wants to be a sincere exploration of faith and forgiveness but somehow manages to be both too innocuous and too off-putting for its own good.
An incredible work that will continue to haunt you, long after it is over.
Fast, furious and insanely entertaining.
While it is far from Ozon's worst movie, it is perhaps the first one he's made that feels like it could be the work of any other director.
The best thing about Beauty and the Beast by a wide margin is the performance by Emma Watson as Belle.
It has nothing to say about anything and the way that it plays on our own fears regarding the epidemic of real-life office violence is more grotesque than it is provocative.

If there is a silver lining to Song to Song, it is the simple fact that even though it is ultimately a failure as a film, it is indeed a Terrence Malick through and through that he has made without any hint of compromise.
An uncommonly smart, well-made and ultimately touching meditation on grief, revenge and the ordinary perils of adolescence that should resonate strongly with adults and thoughtful teenagers alike.
The acknowledgment that it is aiming solely for the kiddie audience this time around at least makes it slightly more palatable than its predecessors.
Has enough skill and personality going for it to make it worth checking out, even if it doesn't quite live up (or down, depending on your perspective) to its borderline sleazy premise.
The result is a film that is so funny and wise and thoughtful that yeah, I guess you could call it poetic.
A depressingly familiar (when it isn't just depressing) thriller.
Certain Women should prove to be a film to treasure.
Unlike so many films of its type, this is one of the rare times when the idea of another sequel feels more like a promise than a threat.
There are a number of impressive action set pieces to be had here, including one of the more hellacious car chases to hit the screen in a while.
Ugly and ham-fisted where it should be exciting and edifying, "Desierto" comes up short both as blood-soaked entertainment and as a blood-stirring polemic.
A wildly inconsequential action-comedy that contains a couple of genuine laughs but which otherwise feels like an extended version of its own television ads.
Funny, thrilling, gripping and, yes, filled with imaginatively staged carnage.
The big twist is so ridiculous that viewers will more likely find themselves laughing at its sheer silliness than reeling from its dramatic rug-pulling.
A grandly entertaining stab at old-fashioned storytelling buoyed by smart and stylish filmmaking, a good performance by Brad Pitt and an even better one from Marion Cotillard.
Incarnate is such a pointless bit of hackwork that it almost makes the recent horror dud Shut In seem focused by comparison.
An embarrassingly murky mess that takes something that could've been made into agreeably cheeseball fun and sucks all the fun out of it.
To think that everyone here intended to make a movie this utterly lifeless and banal from the outset is infinitely more frightening than anything presented on screen.
Resident Evil: The Final Chapter may not be the ideal final note for the series but as long as Jovovich is up there doing her thing, most people will be too enthralled to notice.
More wearying than frightening, Rings is a total non-starter.
Filled with righteous anger, sly wit and genuine creepiness, Get Out is a savvy, stylish and enormously entertaining film.
Fifty Shades Darker is a film so profoundly awful that no one involved with it comes out looking good.
Apart from the presumed financial incentive -- the original did pretty well in theaters and was a big hit on home video -- why was Bad Santa 2 even made in the first place?
When it is good, it is really, really good but when it winds up going south, it does it so completely that it hardly seems possible that the same people could have been responsible for both halves.
It has been made with a lot of style and skill and comes across as much more than the simple cash-in opportunity that it might have initially appeared to be when it was first announced.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While it may lack the out-of-nowhere surprise factor of the first film, The LEGO Batman Movie is a more-than-worthy extension of both the LEGO and Batman screen franchises.
The end result is a film that arrives with undeniably noble intentions but which sadly falls apart when it comes to execution.

The best thing that can be said about "W.E." is that as failed bits of year-end Oscar bait involving England in the 20th century go, it is better than "The Iron Lady." Unfortunately, it isn't that much better.
It's frustrating that Hell or High Water contains so many good things that just don't coalesce into a fully satisfying moviegoing experience.
A cheerfully old-fashioned spook show that could have been produced back in the Fifties with the likes of Cushing and/or Lee with nary a change
A film that is one of the very best of the year and which officially launches Reitman into the top ranks of major American filmmakers.
A surprisingly nimble and low-key treatment of a story that could have easily be blown up into a portentous drag
A weird and only occasionally successful pastiche of time-honored themes that has enough interesting aspects to make it worth seeing but not enough the instant classic that it dearly wants to be.
Little more than this decade's "The Phantom Menace," both in terms of the intense expectations that it has generated and the shockingly banal ways in which it fails to live up to them.
The film couldn't be more square or old-fashioned if it tried
It knows exactly what it wants to do and does it with a minimum of muss and fuss and that is more than I can say for a lot of the other movies that I have seen lately.
The work of a filmmaker at the peak of his powers and is one of the few genuine must-sees of the season.
When you compare its promise and pedigree with the ultimate results, there is no getting around the fact that it is one of the more disappointing films of the season.
This is a film that does roughly the same thing for the concept of star-powered romantic comedies that Tiger Woods has done for the concept of marital fidelity.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps Rob Marshall suffers from an unconscionable disconnect from the material.

a terrible and terribly dated work that will strike Williams scholars as the cinematic equivalent of a bottle cap and everyone else as arguably the worst version of one of his works to ever hit the big screen and bear in mind, I have seen "Boom."
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One trip to the poisoned post-apocalyptic well too many
An astonishingly tone-deaf work that is one of the most utterly misguided literary adaptations to hit the big screen in recent memory.

the kind of instantly forgettable film that seems to have been designed to play in empty multiplexes in the early weeks of the year before the movies that people actually want to see finally start coming out.
A work so screeching awful and irritating that it almost makes "Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel" seem palatable by comparison.
On the grand scale of convincing romantic melodramas, "Dear John" falls somewhere between "Antichrist" and "From Paris With Love."
"Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel" is pure cinematic poison from start to finish and does roughly for holiday moviegoing what Irving Mainway's Bag O'Glass once did for holiday gift-giving.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It wastes a good cast and a potentially moving premise by hammering the sentimentality home so relentlessly that the Paul McCartney tune that plays over the end credits comes across as tough as nails by comparison.

"New Moon" is a terrible, terrible movie that is essentially "Transformers 2" for the training bra set with pseudo-soulful glances from bare-chested boys substituting for giant robots blowing things up.

One of the oddest family-oriented movies in recent memory--perhaps the first one to have its lead character simultaneously emblazoned on Happy Meal boxes and the cover of "Film Comment" and seem perfectly home in both places
You know that you are in a really bad omnibus film when it turns out that Brett Ratner's contribution is actually one of the better ones on display.

Comparing the original to this one is like comparing regular basketball to donkey basketball--a perfectly good thing has been needlessly "improved" by making everything bigger and dumber and by allowing a bunch of jackasses to dump all over it.
The nicest thing that you can say about it is that it isn't quite as contemptuous of its audience as the incredibly lazy and unnecessary "Saw V" was.

As a behind-the-scenes look at how a concert of this size and scope actually comes together, "This Is It" is undeniably intriguing but as a testament to the artistic talents of Michael Jackson, it comes up short in many areas.
A leaden and ugly mess that offers all the emotional and dramatic heft of an exceptionally garish Christmas window display.

So overdone that at a certain point,it begins to resemble one of those demented and depraved melodramatic satires that John Waters used to specialize in back in the days before "Hairspray" made him respectable.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If aliens from another world ever do come to Earth and get a look at "The Fourth Kind," they may decide that any species capable of creating anything this dumb is probably too stupid to probe and conquer in the first place.
And yet, while "The Men Who Stare at Goats" may not completely succeed as a whole, it has so many worthwhile individual elements that it should not be completely written off either.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What seems on the surface to be just another hacky sellout from a once-interesting filmmaker on the commercial skids is actually one of the most genuinely freaky and fascinating films of the year.
Not so much a film as it is the world's dullest diorama brought to semi-life.
By the end, "Tormented" is such a listless take on a potentially interesting idea that it feels like its own remake.
Those who don't know art but who know what they like are likely to come away from "(Untitled)" thinking "Gee, I could have done that."
A graceless mess that will insult the intelligence of everyone who encounters it, even those who were actually looking forward to seeing it in the first place.
It may not completely succeed as a horror film, though I would take its deliberately funky and low-key vibe over the hard-sell nonsense of "Paranormal Activity" any day of the week.

There is a great movie to be made from this particular subject--something along the lines of such cult favorites as "American Hot Wax" and "24 Hour Party People"--but alas, "Pirate Radio" is not that movie.

The only good thing to say about this brutal and brutally boring bit of blarney is that it is so relentlessly unpleasant and unappealing that we may never have to endure the likes of "The Boondock Saints III: Get Boondockier."
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Stretched to nearly two full hours and deploying a seemingly endless array of flashbacks sequences, it becomes almost impossible to follow for more than a few minutes at a time and Jaa's utterly charm-free performance doesn't make things any easier.
one of the more entertaining and engaging pop entertainments to come along in a while despite its excesses and even because of them at certain points.
While it may not necessarily reinvent the genre, it beats the likes of "The Ugly Truth" or "Leap Year" like a gong.

One of those incredibly frustrating works that has so many things going for it that it becomes almost painful to watch as it falls far short of what it might have achieved if it possessed a better screenplay as well.

A film that brilliantly balances artistic and commercial considerations in ways that are sure to impress both cineastes and people simply looking for something entertaining to see at the local multiplex on a Saturday night.

Come back, "Gigli"--most everything is forgiven.
loud, garish, stupid, brutish, racist, sexist and utterly devoid of wit, intelligence, grace, dignity or any other commonly held humanistic ideals.
The bastard film of 100 idiots.
This one may provide some temporary thrills but they are empty ones that will largely be forgotten within a couple of days.
So vapid and shallow that even the most devoutly Catholic viewers will find themselves agreeing that it never comes close to become a viable film.
As pointless and nearly unendurable low-budget grotesqueries filled with stomach-churning imagery go, it is definitely a step up from "Babies."
It recognizes that a film about unpleasant people need not be unpleasant itself as long as it remembers not to make them uninteresting as well.

It grabs viewers right from the start, carries them along at a breakneck pace for more than two hours and then sends them off into the lobby feeling dazed, dizzy and delighted over what they have just experienced.

movie_review_blurb: So unrelievedly slow and solemn throughout that it feels more like an exceptionally rigid museum tour than the full-blooded adventure that it should be.
This may be the first screen romance in recent memory where the inclusion of ABBA lyrics might have actually come across as an improvement.
"MacGruber" is a film aimed squarely at the hearts and minds of twelve-year-old boys. This is great if you are a twelve-year-old boy, of course, but not so much so if you aren't.
This is nothing more than a tired and creatively bankrupt attempt to further stretch out a property that never should have turned into a franchise in the first place.

There are many words that could be used to describe "Kites" in a review--indeed, even the trusty Oxford English Dictionary almost seems inadequate for such a task--but "boring" is most definitely not one of them.
