Ritchie is all about the whooshing and headbanging, leaving no space between Holmes' words to savor their meaning. Downey is irresistible. The movie, not so much.
Rob Marshall's flawed but frequently dazzling Nine is a hot-blooded musical fantasia full of song, dance, raging emotion and simmering sexuality.
It extends the possibilities of what movies can do. Cameron's talent may just be as big as his dreams.
Eastwood's modest approach to these momentous events shames the usual Hollywood showboating. In a rare achievement, he's made a film that truly is good for the soul.
It's a juicy, career-crowning role, and Bridges -- a master of subtle brilliance -- plays the hell out of it.
The novel never flinched, the movie does. But Jackson, who builds jolting suspense when Susie's sister enters the killer's lair, is drawn to a spiritual dimension.
Ford is a true visionary, but it's his humanity that gives the love story a ravishing, bruised grandeur.
Helen Mirren is a lusty, roaring wonder playing, of all things, the long-suffering wife of Russian novelist Leo Tolstoy (Christopher Plummer in peak form).

First-time director and screenwriter Hue Rhodes shows no discernible talent for dialogue, humor and, especially, pacing. For a movie than runs a mere 85 minutes, Saint John moves like a life sentence in molasses prison.
Crushing dull repetition that makes one noisy, violent scene play exactly like the last one.
Indecently exploits 9/11 and throws in autism and canver for unscrupulous measure.
The Wolfman bites, but not -- I think -- in the way the filmmakers intended.
The Greatest takes a piece out of you.
So bad it makes The Notebook look like Casablanca.
The film is a sham, with good actors going for the paycheck and using beards and heavy makeup to hide their shame.
The best of Egoyan's films (The Sweet Hereafter, Exotica) deserve serious attention. Not this time.
City Island is a relief for filmgoers dulled by Hollywood formula. Despite lapses into overstatement, it's nothing but good, sweet, breezy times.
Hot Tub Time Machine should have been better than this.
Say what you will about the Runaways -- they never played it safe. The movie does.

If you ignore The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo (from the global bestseller by the late Stieg Larsson) because it's in Swedish with English subtitles, you probably deserve the remake Hollywood will surely screw up.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Kid stuff? Maybe. But How to Train Your Dragon, from the book by Cressida Cowell, works enough miracles of 3-D animation to charm your socks off.
Here's proof that Tina Fey and Steve Carell could squeeze laughs out of a phone book.
Baumbach tracks Roger without glib condescension. That's why Greenberg pulls you in. Even when you laugh, like in the climactic party scene, it hurts.
She's Out of My League is a rowdy blast because the spiky young cast treats the played-out script like virgin territory. That's acting!
Too little and too late? Maybe. But even in this Bourne Zone, Damon and Greengrass haven't shirked their duty to enlighten and entertain.
Even Disney and a PG rating can't bury Burton's subversive wit. Like Carroll, he's a master at dressing up psychic wounds in fantasy.
Brooklyn's Finest is a cop movie so shallow, dumb, derivative and infuriating that it feels like a parody of bad cop movies.
Director Jacques Audiard scores a triumph of the highest order with the defiant poetry of his vision.
An early scene of Morgan scaring a perp with tough dialogue from movies reminded me of primo Smith. Other scenes not so much.
Shows Polanski in brilliant command of a political thriller that ties you up in knots of tension while zinging politics and showbiz like two sides of the same toxic coin.
Martin Scorsese makes movies as if his life depends on it, never skimping on ferocity and feeling.
Valentine's Day is a date movie from hell. How did director Garry Marshall persuade a big name cast to stuff themselves into this box of rancid heart-shaped chocolates?
It's all weepy drool until the twist ending, which turns it shockingly offensive.
One-word reaction: bravo.
It's not the age of the actors that makes The Expendables expendable. It's the stale storytelling.
Step up for a pulverizing Aussie crime drama that cuts to the dark heart of the killing machine known as family.
The January movie burial ground claims another victim. RIP.
The big-screen Green Hornet, while hardly classic comic-book filmmaking, ain't half bad.
Country Strong is dead on arrival.
Season of the Witch is as bloodless as a starved vampire. Instead of a review, it deserves a stake in the heart.
It would be impossible to list the Oscar-worthy performances of 2010 without highlighting Javier Bardem in Biutiful.
Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams give two of the most explosive and emotionally naked performances you will see anywhere.
This haunting movie hits you hard and right where you live.
The second sequel to 2000's Meet the Parents defines uncalled for. Little Fockers is upchuckingly unfunny.
As in Lost in Translation, Coppola keeps an eye out for the broken places. That's when Somewhere is really something.
The Coens have crafted a vastly entertaining Wild West show that is memorable in every particular.

Kidman, doing her best work in years, just comes at you. Her final scene with the splendid Wiest, who builds her character with uncommon feeling, is devastating. So is the movie. It takes a piece out of you.
This movie, with its flashbacks to past sins and traumas, rests squarely on Berry, a mesmerizer who makes every moment count.
Golden Globe nominee Kevin Spacey has a ball and then some playing the devil inside Jack Abramoff, the corrupt GOP lobbyist who ran wild during the W. years.
Director Joseph Kosinski has a recipe for adventure that should delight gamers. Non-techies are on their own.
I found myself wishing that Taymor would turn off the sound and fury and let The Tempest speak for itself. My wish wasn't granted.
In a year of craptaculars, The Tourist deserves burial at the bottom of the 2010 dung heap.
The Fighter, its heart full to bursting, is an emotional powerhouse that comes close to spilling over.
Night Catches Us, Tanya Hamilton's first feature as a director, is something to cherish.
The movie, written and directed by John Requa and Glen Ficara of Bad Santa fame, is all over the place. But it's also outrageously funny.
It's an impossible task trying to squeeze Mordecai Richler's sprawling novel about an SOB into one little movie. But they lucked out with first-rate actors.
This artful tale of survival against the elements - radiating terror and beauty - continues Peter Weir's fascination with characters trapped by worlds they didn't make.

After the heavy dramatic lifting of Black Swan, you can't fault Oscar favorite Natalie Portman for signing up for some romcom R&R. It's too bad she couldn't have landed a less generic vehicle than No Strings Attached.
The result is just good enough to pass as an action flick you watch with the forgiving gaze that comes from too many beers and too little sleep.
Cedar Rapids is both hilarious and heartfelt. It's also powered by a dream cast, led by the outstanding Ed Helms.
Don't even think of going with it. It's the perfect Valentine's date night movie, but only with someone you hate.
Never Say Never is a 3D concert film to delight the shy 13-year-old with braces that lives in all of us, but after a while the movie starts to feel like lethal injection by bubblegum.
Sometimes the sets look like, well, Styrofoam. So do the actors.
The Roommate - the umpteenth uncredited remake of 1992's Single White Female - sucks bad, real bad.
Quote not available.
[A] dumb excuse for a movie.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
All Good Things throws so many narrative balls in the air that you may struggle to catch up. It's worth the effort. Jarecki is a master of the telling detail.
Quote not available.
It's fun for about 15 minutes seeing Neeson do James Bond as Daddy Dangerous. But the surprise wears off quickly.
Mike Leigh's films are one of a kind.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Precious is an emotional powerhouse, a triumph of bruising humor and bracing hope that deserves its place among the year's best films.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Is redemption possible for this bad lieutenant? At one point, he orders that a dead man be shot again because "his soul is still dancing." If you find God in that line, then welcome to your movie heaven.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Kaboom is an erotic blast of sinful flesh, fun and fantasy that you don't want to stop.
The Rite goes wrong in every way.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie left me with the feeling of being trapped with a person of privilege who won't stop with the whine whine whine.
Portman's portrait of an artist under siege is unmissable and unforgettable. So is the movie. You won't know what hit you.
Rated a family-friendly PG-13, Burlesque never loses its s---, never gets erotically out of hand, never devolves into delicious camp.
This movie isn't just a necessity (listen up, do-nothing politicians) - it might change your future.
Ninety minutes of being buried alive with Ryan Reynolds: Didn't we all suffer that in The Proposal?
The Social Network is the movie of the year. But Fincher and Sorkin triumph by taking it further. Lacing their scathing wit with an aching sadness, they define the dark irony of the past decade.
Stone used to know in his gut that a sermon belongs in the pulpit, not the multiplex. No more.
Making his debut behind the camera, Oscar winner Philip Seymour Hoffman directs like he acts, with a sharp eye for the small details that cut to the soul of a character.
The jokes are hit-and-miss. But Stone is one sassy babe and a breakout star who nails every zinger and brings genuine warmth to her scenes with her parents.
Here's a movie you can't get out of your head, a sci-fi horror story with the seductive allure of a classic romance.
There's more killer suspense and shocking intimacy in this one-of-a-kind documentary than you'll find in a dozen thrillers. You'll laugh hard and cry too.
Ben Affleck, 38, kicks it up a notch with The Town, a gripping human drama disguised as a blazing heist film that comes on like gangbusters.

Instead of Rachel Getting Married with an Oscar-nominated Anne Hathaway, we get Galt Niederhoffer's misbegotten, miscast snoozefest with Katie Holmes struggling to prove that there is life as an actress while still being Mrs. Tom Cruise.
I'm not sure I believed a word of this film. Actors who melt down on camera are usually, well, acting. But I couldn't take my eyes off I'm Still Here.
Still, The American is remote to a fault. Like Jack (George Clooney), it seems in danger of turning to stone.
Barrymore and Long are both appealing, but not enough to sustain audience interest in the cinematic equivalent of dry-humping.
This unholy mess replaces the artful ambition of The American with torture, blood spray, kinky sex, twisted fun and a bizarro critique of U.S. policy on illegal immigration.
Piranha 3D ends the summer on a note of shamelessly entertaining B movie bottomfeeding.
It's not just the hand-held camera that will shake you up. The Last Exorcism gives you good reason to be very afraid of the dark.
This movie sucks more.
This documentary succeeds triumphantly on so many levels that its full impact doesn't hit you until you have time to register its aftershocks
The film offers few - make that no - surprises. What almost saves it is the acting.
I thought for sure that any Hollywood remake of Tomas Alfredson's artful Swedish vampire film, Let the Right One In, would be a crass desecration. Well, color me blushing.
Galifianakis is a comic force of nature, but he digs down here and delivers a beautifully nuanced performance that gets under your skin. Just like the movie.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Don't fret when the film gets stuck in stodgy mud. Just bask in the glory that was Secretariat, and watch that horse ride.
This is crap as we know it, a 113 minute package of romcom suck.
Disney's spirited re-telling of Rapunzel in 3D animation turns out to be a dazzler.
The King's Speech -- a crowning achievement powered by a dream cast -- digs vibrant human drama out of the dry dust of history.
Sally Hawkins is just plain irresistible in this funny, touching and vital salute to women in the work force.
It's damn hard to enjoy a thriller when you don't, won't, can't believe a word of it.
Like a virgin's padded bra, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part I is all tease, zero payoff.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Tiny Furniture, winner of the SXSW festival's best narrative feature prize, gets under your skin. It's the work of a filmmaker with a stunning future.
Morning Glory is a tart, terrific comedy that gives Harrison Ford his best and funniest role in years.
Unstoppable is a bang-up ride that means to wring you out. Mission accomplished.
Naomi Watts and Sean Penn bring ferocity and feeling to their roles, turning a potent political thriller into a stirring, relatable human drama.
This movie is best treated like dim sum. Wait out the bad portions until a tastier dish is served. Let Hathaway be your guide.
Is Due Date the new Hangover? It is not. But it has its own rewards.

Danny Boyle pumps every frame of 127 Hours with cinematic adrenaline that declares war on the dull gravity of docudrama. And James Franco does the best, most natural and nuanced acting of his career to date, lacing terror with bracing humor.
The actors and admirably sensitive director Jake Scott (son of Ridley) can't compensate for Ken Hixon's long slog of a script.
Hornet's Nest is talky but indisputably terrific, and it ends in a dazzling display of courtroom fireworks. Rapace is hot stuff in any language. Oscar, take heed.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you're looking for wicked fun this Halloween, Paranormal Activity 2 is the best goosebump game in town.
It's a dynamite movie, and you can see it in the full 330-minute version or the 140-minute cut. Either way, see it. It'll knock you sideways.
Conviction sweetens the true story it's based on, and director Tony Goldwyn dutifully connects the dots in Pam Gray's screenplay.
Hereafter, set to a resonant Eastwood score, truly is haunting.
The Jackass guys, goaded on again by fearless leader Johnny Knoxville and director Jeff Tremaine, don't seem as eager to outrage as they once were.
Nowhere Boy is smart enough not to spell it all out. You can hear it in Lennon's music, which plays in your head as the movie works its subtle magic.
What this raucous 3D animated fun house lacks in originality (think bastard child of The Incredibles and Despicable Me) it makes up for in visual and vocal wit.
What do you say about a movie that proves Zac Efron can act, introduces a master thespian in Christian McKay and launches a charm assault that is damn near irresistible?

In this haunting portrait of America as no country for old men or young, Hillcoat -- through the artistry of Mortensen and Smit-McPhee -- carries the fire of our shared humanity and lets it burn bright and true.
I can't comment on the acting because I didn't catch Pattinson, Stewart and Lautner doing any. They basically primp and pose through the same humdrum motions they did before.
Directed with extraordinary skill by Sam Mendes, the film is a tough road well worth traveling.
Waltz With Bashir is hallucinatory brilliance in the service of understanding the psychic damage of war.
The shortage of wit and the excess of goo can be summed up in Sandler's line to these children of divorce: 'I'm like the stink on your feet -- I'll always be there.'
Watching the stars try to out-cutesy the mutt is one for the puke bucket.
The movie looks amazing. And for the first hour, when storytelling and special effects bond like lovers, it plays even better.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you're thinking 'yuck,' you're right.
Lurie has crafted a different kind of thriller, one with a mind and a heart.
It'll pin you to your seat.
Simple story, beautifully told.
A lifetime in movies runs through this prime vintage Eastwood performance. You can't take your eyes off him. The no-frills, no-bull Gran Torino made my day.
[Winslet's] fierce, unerring portrayal goes beyond acting, becoming a provocation that will keep you up nights.
Too bad for Knowles that she's only part of Darnell Martin's rushed mess of a movie that jams the story of Chicago-based Chess Records into one incoherent package.
A film version of a play about two talking heads. Please. It shouldn't work at all. But it does work, spectacularly, as a matter of fact.
Beautiful scenery and the best intentions can't save Australia from dissolving in goo.
My advice: Focus on Pattinson and Stewart. They make you understand why the books sold 17 million copies.
Here's the little movie that could, a potent directing debut for actor Robert Davi.
Slumdog Millionaire has the goods to bust out as a scrappy contender in the Oscar race. It's modern India standing in for a world in full economic spin.
Dark secrets are unlocked, words draw more blood than punches, and [director] Desplechin turns one family into a universe that resembles life as a startling work of art.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Quantum of Solace won't trust its own darker instincts. It delivers the popcorn goods, but it ignores the poison eating at Bond's insides. Killer mistake.

Tom Cruise starring in the fact-based story of a plot to kill Hitler by Nazi Col. Claus von Stauffenberg sounds like Oscar bait. It isn't. And the sooner you accept it, the more fun you'll have at this satisfying B movie.
Quote not available.
Even when this 'authorized' movie biography makes you long for the 'explicit' version, Woolard's tour de force finds the human details that forged an artist and lets Biggie fly.
For all the film's flaws, this is a war story told with passion about a band of brothers that still has the power to inspire.
An animated funhouse that delivers on its title and ups its scary-comic impact if you see it in 3-D.
Shockingly immediate and philosophically reflective, Hunger is an indelibly moving tribute to what makes us human.
Gilroy and his stars make it elegant fun to be fooled, but they sure as hell make you work for it.
In a down market for giggles (Miss March? Please!), Paul Rudd and Jason Segel are howlingly funny. They have skills.
Audiences with a brain cell left have only one choice: Look for the first exit on the right.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This funny and touching movie depends on two can-do actresses to scrub past the biohazard of noxious clichés that threaten to intrude. Adams and Blunt get the job done. They come highly recommended.
Let Clarkson and Fanning take you to the rabbit hole of seductive enchantment that defines this movie.
You have to go back to the comic to learn that the freaks in Watchmen are not only for geeks, maybe that's not so bad. Just sayin'.

It's no mystery that the target audience for this G-rated bubblegum fantasy is tweens, parents of tweens and the occasional pervert. They'll be so pleased. Anything for the rest of humanity? Not so much.
Talented actors are involved, and I will spare them by not citing their names.
Trust Kramer, though, to spring surprises with the help of a risk-taking cast.
Quote not available.
Bravely wearing his heart on his sleeve, James Gray directs the tender and terrific Two Lovers as an antidote to the virus of hip.
Confessions is no more than a painless time-waster. But the beguiling Fisher is well worth the investment.
OK, it doesn't tell you much about the role of banks in the current economic free-fall. But if you want to know, it's a humdinger of a stimulus package.
Wasn't it bad enough the first time?
Are women desperate or just desperately stupid? This is the misogynist question at the core of He's Just Not That Into You, a women-bashing tract disguised as a chick flick.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's not just the 3-D glasses that add an extra dimension to the horror and hilarity of Coraline.
The thudding sounds you hear at New In Town are jokes landing like lead balloons and conking the life out of the actors.
Laurent Cantet's scrappy mesmerizer of a movie about a life in learning sneaks up and floors you.
Even if you've never heard of Project Runway, the battle between art and wicked compromise never goes out of style.

Director Justin Lin still hasn't learned film geography. Even the kinetic tunnel races, meant to nitrocharge the movie, fall flat from spatial incoherence. You barely know what's happening, and to whom.
The premise doesn't excuse lapses in logic, but the power of the story and the performances is indisputable.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Soul Men is a chance to salute these masters of mirth and music. Take it.
Appaloosa is gripping entertainment that keeps springing surprises.
Lakeview Terrace is obvious when you most want it to be stealth.
Righteous Kill, a.k.a. The Al and Bob Show, is a cop flick with all the drama of Law and Order: AARP.
[Director] Ball throws out so many provocations in Towelhead that it's no surprise a few land with a thud. But there's no questioning his talent for filmmaking. He's got the gift.

A big-name cast of actresses gives it a go, but everyone from Meg Ryan as the cheated-on wife to Eva Mendes as the home-wrecking perfume girl struggles with a script that resists being crowbarred into the 21st century.
It would be no country for movie lovers without the Coens. They still manage to run unmuzzled while the rest of Hollywood runs scared.
A spellbinder you do not want to miss.
It's Coogan's breakthrough star performance that holds it all together. He's sensational.
Herzog is one of a kind. His new doc is an event you watch in awe as you marvel at its wonders.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In this light-comic breeze of a movie, Cruz is a gathering storm.

Think of all the ways you can hurt yourself laughing, as in fall down, split your sides, bust a gut, blow your mind. You get it all in Tropic Thunder, a knockout of a comedy that keeps you laughing constantly.
Bottle Shock is something special: there's magic in it.
Rogen, Franco and McBride are on the march into stoner legend.
The new Mummy is, how can I put it? Just freakin' awful.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: These American teens really get under your skin. You'll be pissed. You'll be perplexed. You'll be totally riveted.
movie_title: Six Sex Scenes and a Murder (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You'll be totally riveted.
In not knowing who it needs to please, I Want to Believe pleases no one.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Starting at infantile and regressing hysterically from there, Step Brothers flies on the comic chemistry of Will Ferrell and John C. Reilly.
To my surprise, a diamond has emerged from the gutter. Its name is The World's End, and it'll knock you on you ass from laughing when you're not rubbing your eyes in disbelief.
The fall movie season achieves comic liftoff thanks to Ricky Gervais, a master of deadpan hilarity playing a dentist who sees dead people.
It's Knightley who makes The Duchess a royal treat.
If there's a Southern-gothic cliché (oh, those snakes!) that writer-director Deborah Kampmeier misses, I don't know it.
Kinnear takes the star spot in Flash of Genius and rides it to glory.
Rogen and Banks, both terrific, bring out the sweet and spicy best in each other.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Want a master class in film acting? Check out Kristin Scott Thomas as Juliette, a doctor just out of prison in this spellbinder from writer-director Philippe Claudel.
A mesmerizing film that burns in the memory.
It's that rare bird in our debased pop culture that gives you something to chew on when you leave the theater besides where to go for dinner.
Efron and co-star Vanessa Hudgens have charm. But director Kenny Ortega buries them in formula dances, forgettable tunes and dialogue that makes Grease sound like Greek tragedy.

Ostensibly about a steadily imploding Irish-cop family in New York, Pride and Glory sizzles with a subversive subtext that questions blind loyalty to institutions, from the White House to Wall Street, that keep selling us out.
Even the target audience of 10-year-olds might get jimmy legs sitting for a punishing 135 minutes as the Wachowski brothers projectile-vomit their cotton-candy dreams all over the big screen.
Did everyone involved in this botched thriller OD on speed?
Quote not available.
Sometimes a shamelessly stoopid, proudly profane R-rated comedy is all you want out of life. Role Models more than fills the bill.
Max just drags on as it drags you down. If you stay and watch the endless end credits, there's a short scene that hints a sequel is coming. That's what I call real pain.
Whatever you think of Dubya, he has balls. The movie doesn't.
Quote not available.
No list of the year's best performances should be made without [Sally Hawkins].
Great title for a gangster flick. Too bad that writer-director Guy Ritchie only partially realizes the sizzling potential.
Except for watching Bill Murray get attacked by a giant mole (something unique in Billy boy's career so far) this sci-fi fantasy aimed at kids feels wan and warmed over.
Quote not available.
Demme calls Rachel Getting Married a "home movie." A home run is more like it, going deep into the joy and pain of being human.
Bill Maher would have been burned at the stake if his hellishly hilarious and surprisingly thoughtful satire on organized religion had played the Inquisition.
The script is Afterschool Special 101.
It's a tossup. Your call.
Adventureland throws a lot at us, but not enough of it sticks.
Boden and Fleck are exceptional talents who refuse to sweeten Sugar for mass consumption. The result is raw and riveting.
Director and co-writer Derick Martini throws all this drama on a high burner. Even when the drama gets overcooked, Lymelife sends off sparks.
Director Karyn Kusama is torn between duty to female empowerment and slasher convention. But Fox shows a comic flair that Transformers never investigated.
What I can't figure out is how director Peter Hyams can remake a 1956 movie from the great Fritz Lang and not learn anything about suspense, pacing and storytelling in the process.
Wintour steers a tight ship. Coddington reminds her that Vogue has a history based on something more than profit. In the end, they're a winning combination.
Here's a powerhouse of a documentary that makes you feel mad as hell and unwilling to take it anymore.
[An] unwatchable, unbearably unfunny farce in which Sandra Bullock hits the lowest point of her career...
Right in time for the economic downturn comes Extract, a smart and potently funny workplace comedy about running a small business just as small businesses get routinely run into the ground.
Robert Siegel makes a potent directing debut with a scrappy movie that refuses to sentimentalize or ridicule its besieged hero worshipper.

All the tie-dye, reefer, skinny-dipping, split-screen cinematography (from Eric Gautier) and acid-trip psychedelics courtesy of Tiber's encounter with hippies (Paul Dano and Kelli Garner) can't make up for the film's major sin of omission: the music.
The invigorating result, zestily edited by Lee's own inside iron man, Barry Brown, is in every way a knockout.
Will Basterds polarize audiences? That's a given. But for anyone professing true movie love, there's no resisting it.
Does this sound like rock heaven? It is.
Props to Kutcher for going to surprising, painful places. There's something haunted in his portrayal that hits hard and sticks.
Miyazaki works marvels. Sit back and behold.
I'd watch the vibrant Rachel McAdams and Eric Bana in anything, but The Time Traveler's Wife is pushing it.
This baby has the stuff to end the movie summer on a note of dazzle and distinction.
I could load you up with more plot details, but this mercilessly incoherent, galactically stupid movie left me too numb to type.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The ideal recipe has a special ingredient that can lift a dish from meh to memorable. Meryl Streep -- at her brilliant, beguiling best -- is the spice that does the trick for the yummy Julie & Julia.
Enjoying this wondrous wisp of a something is easy, describing it is hard. Luckily, Charlyne Yi is an enchantress.
The film is superbly shot by Andrij Parekh and edited by Andrew Mondshein, but it's the hilarious and heartbreaking Giamatti who provides it with, well, soul.
A literate, lyrical love story in the age of Hollywood crass. I must be dreaming.

Shooting fast and digital in just 30 days, Soderbergh invests the film with the breathless pace of a thriller and the gravity befitting a nation's soul sickness. Damon makes Whitacre recognizably human.

OK, it sounds like a tear-jerker, and sometimes it drifts dangerously close. But Owen, in a heartfelt, award-caliber performance, never goes soft. It's his core of toughness that makes the movie so funny, touching and vital.
Moore sees our abusive relationship with capitalism as a growing plague. His movie, a genuine and welcome rabble-rouser, lays out the history of how democracy got corrupted.
The Messenger, showing humanity under siege, opens wounds inflicted by the Iraq War -- not on the battlefield but in the hearts of the families of soldiers who never made it back home.
Beware 2012, which works the dubious miracle of almost matching Transformers 2 for sheer, cynical, mind-numbing, time-wasting, money-draining, soul-sucking stupidity.
The boat nearly sinks from character overload, and Curtis brakes when you most want him to gun it. But there's no denying the comic energy of the cast.
An adventure in pure imagination that plays to the smart kid in all of us.
Instead of sweeping you along, The Box just sits there like something unclaimed at lost and found. Damaged goods.
It's hard to resist a satire, even when it wobbles, that insists the most unbelievable parts are the most true.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Jackson's perfectionism fails him in This Is It, and we're all the better for it.
Jammed with story threads that don't cohere, Cirque commits the cardinal sin for a vampire movie: It's bloodless.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: "Who wants a life imprisoned in safety?" Amelia asks in a voice-over. And you want to shout, "This movie does, honey." There's not a real or spontaneous minute in it.
It has the breathless pace of a Bourne movie, but none of the comfort of fiction. This is documentary filmmaking at its most exciting and purposeful.
An exercise in illogic and Death Wish cribbing that lets a bunch of good actors collect big paychecks for playing way less than their A game.

For all the money spent, the film's success is best measured by its simplicity and the purity of its innovation. Jonze has filmed a fantasy as if it were absolutely real, allowing us to see the world as Max sees it, full of beauty and terror.
A quiet miracle of a movie that quickly disabuses you of the idea that you've seen it all before.

The cast got to spend a month shooting on Bora Bora. So that explains why they're in the movie. Why you'd spend good money for a ticket to watch them have all the fun and not have any fun yourself passes understanding.
Tom Hardy is pure dynamite in the role, beefing up 35 pounds to play Britain's most notorious prisoner.
Screenwriter Shauna Cross dulls the edges of her novel Derby Girl, which the skate action and rockin' soundtrack can't disguise.
It's no fun watching Gervais work out a tired fantasy of turning hot babes into chubby chasers. We want Gervais in all his merry, malicious glory. That's no lie.
This seriously funny movie, artfully photographed by the great Roger Deakins, is spiritual in nature, barbed in tone, and, oh, yeah, it stings like hell.
Director Ruben Fleischer mixes fright and slapstick with bloody glee. And the surprise star cameo is a wowser. Enough said.
With a $15,000 budget too puny to empty a petty-cash drawer, the no-frills Paranormal Activity comes packed with thrills.
Von Trier says he was suffering from severe bouts of depression when he shot the movie. See Antichrist, and you'll know the feeling.
Apatow scores by crafting the film equivalent of a stand-up routine that encompasses the joy, pain, anger, loneliness and aching doubt that go into making an audience laugh.
Toss this ugly crap to the curb, along with the other multiplex garbage, and see a romance that gets it right. I'm talking (500) Days of Summer.
In the Loop deserves to be a sleeper hit. The whole cast is stellar. And it proves that smart and funny can exist in the same movie, even in summer.
Lots of films are called haunting, Summer Hours truly is.
Without pretensions to profundity, the movie can be enjoyed for the hell-raising hooey it is.
Luna and García Bernal display the kind of chemistry that makes you overlook the clichés in the script by first-time director Carlos Cuarón. Sometimes good-natured fun is enough.
This film is a muckraking provocation whose time has come.
Summer officially hits warp speed.
With The Limits of Control, Jim Jarmsuch gets tangled up in his own deadpan.
A transparent attempt to squeeze a faltering franchise for its last drop of box-office juice.
Ghosts of Girlfriends Past never comes as close as spitting distance to a laugh.
I'd call this stenchcloud 'Fatal Attraction meets The Temp,' but that would insult those movies.
Playwright Stephen Belber, in his directing debut, comes close to the sweet spot. He's not there yet. But he'll be worth watching next time.
Do some blow. Curse humanity. Convert to nilhilism. Reread American Psycho. But don't for the love of God and cinema see The Informers.
In the end, The Soloist isn't about BIG MOMENTS, it's about the grace notes, the kind that stay with you.
Quote not available.
Tracing A Chorus Line from its creation in 1974 by Michael Bennett and his dancers to its 2006 Broadway revival, Every Little Step is a thrilling combination of documentary and musical dazzler.
The script hits a few bumps, but Jessica Lange and Drew Barrymore are magnificent as the bizarro Beales.
Blending humor and heartbreak in a performance that makes a small movie a richly satisfying one, Caine truly is magic.
If you can't figure out what happens, you've never seen a movie. And if you haven't, please, God, don't start with this one.
State of Play keeps the twists coming.
Sacha Gervasi's powerhouse doc brings humor and fervent focus to Toronto musicians, supporting their families with day jobs, who won't give up the dream.
Observe and Report revels in creeping you out and making you laugh -- hard.
You won't know what hit you after watching Tyson. This power punch to the gut is one of the best movies of any kind this year.
Ignore the pileup of implausibilities and 'Unknown' becomes a diabolically entertaining con game.
The elegant barbed wit of Noel Coward bubbling up in a time of Wolverine grunts. I must be dreaming.
T4 is a mixed bag, but it's not f------- amateur.
The ending is tidy and way too cute, but (500) Days is otherwise a different kind of love story: an honest one that takes a piece out of you.
Harry is better than ever, a triumph of visual wonder and emotional storytelling.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Aiming for the heartfelt hilarity of Superbad, I Love You, Beth Cooper is just super bad.
Like Swift's Gulliver's Travels, Brüno defies you not to see yourself in its funhouse mirror. And then dares you to laugh it off.
It's movie dynamite.
Transformers: The Revenge of The Fallen is beyond bad, it carves out its own category of godawfulness.
Here's the Iraq War movie for those who don't like Iraq War movies.
With Pfeiffer, 50, radiating uncommon beauty, grace and feeling, Frears uncovers a fragile story's grieving heart.
The infuriating cop-out ending reduces the premise to mush.
Adults who see this movie unaccompanied by a child should sign up pronto for therapy with Gabriel Byrne on In Treatment.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever Works feels like something out of time and, worse, out of step.
A romantic comedy so numbing it feels like Novocaine.

Director Duncan Jones (son of David Bowie), working from a script by Nathan Parker, pulls off sci-fi miracles on a $5 million shoestring. Moon is a potent provocation that relies on ideas instead of computer tricks to stir up excitement.
Don't take another bite till you see Robert Kenner's Food, Inc., an essential, indelible documentary that is scarier than anything in the last five Saw horror shows.
This movie hits you like 600 volts from a sparking third rail. Damn straight it's electrifying.
The Hangover ain't art, but Phillips has shaped the hardcore hilarity into the summer party movie of all our twisted dreams.
Will Ferrell and Danny McBride can find the dumb fun in anything. Too bad that Land of the Lost is so much less than anything.
Up is a breathtaking ride into the realm of pure imagination. Up shames the pap that now passes for family entertainment (yes, Night at the Museum 2, I'm talking to you).
There's no truth in the title. Drag Me to Hell is horror-movie heaven.
What makes The Girlfriend Experience a fresh provocation is not the new ways available to build a fantasy but the near-impossibility of negotiating one you can actually believe in.
If you tamp down your expectations there is a storm of scary fun to be had in this Scandinavian splatterfest.
Everything feels forced. Nothing kills laughter faster than trying too hard.
Shoot me now!
Takes a sweet, long time to work its magic on you.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This story has been filmed many times, but never with this kind of erotic charge. Knightley is glorious. My advice is to let Wright's Anna Karenina work its strange and marvelous spell.
Tinged with shadows and ignited by Lawrence and Cooper, Silver Linings Playbook raises the bar on romantic comedy. It's crazy good.
You're going to hear a lot about Breaking Dawn Part 2 being the best of the Twilight movies. That's like saying a simple head cold is preferable to swine flu.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is Bond like you've never seen him and a dynamite Daniel Craig, never better in the role, nails Bond's ferocity and feeling. Skyfall is smashing, just smashing.
The phenomenal Daniel Day-Lewis plays Lincoln with immersive, indelible power in Spielberg's brilliant, brawling epic.

Grace notes abound in A Late Quartet, a small, shining gem of a movie that works its way into your heart with insinuating potency of music. Walken's performance is heartbreaking, and a master class in the craft of acting.
Wreck-It Ralph is the latest in a rash of recent movies fired up with imaginative risk. Director Moore brings a video junkie's passion to the movie game, and it's hilariously infectious.

Flight reminds us of what Washington can do when a role hits him with a challenge that would floor a lesser actor. He's a ball of fire, and his detailed, depth-charged, bruisingly true performance will be talked about for years.
For all the spectacular settings and visionary designs, Cloud Atlas left me feeling disconnected
If Connery was Sexy Bond and George Lazenby was One-Shot Bond and Roger Moore was Geezer Bond and Timothy Dalton was Bored Bond, then Brosnan should be Posh Bond.
John Hawkes does the kind of acting that awards were invented for in this exhilarating gift of a movie that's funny, touching and vital.
Holy Motors, fueled by pure feeling, is a dream of a movie you want to get lost in.

Ben Affleck doesn't merely direct Argo, he directs the hell out of it, nailing the quickening pace, the wayward humor, the nerve-frying suspense. There's no doubt he's crafted one of the best movies of the year.

What movie junkie out there wouldn't leap at the chance to see merry pranksters such as Christopher Walken, Sam Rockwell and Woody Harrelson go nuts in something called Seven Psychopaths? It's crazy-killer fun.

Addiction dramas are as common as reality shows and often just as rank. Smashed joins the ranks of the winners, mostly because of an unmissable and unforgettable performance by Mary Elizabeth Winstead.
As good as The Ring is, it can't top the original for sheer, shivering terror.
I have seen the new face of movie horror and its name is The Blair Witch Project, a groundbreaker in fright that reinvents scary for the new millennium.
This hot mess got booed by the snobs at Cannes, but there's no denying its profane energy.
Only Tim Burton could envision this Frankenstein-inspired tale, and it's a honey, a dark and dazzling spellbinder that scares up laughs and surprising emotion.
Life of Pi puts 3D in the hands of a worldclass film artist. Ang Lee uses 3D with the delicacy and lyricism of a poet. You don't just watch this movie, you live it.

Hopkins catches the essence of Hitchcock as artist and con man. And Mirren is stellar as his wife and secret weapon. The pleasure of their company adds sparkle to this unexpectedly poignant look at a career and a marriage.
As an orca trainer who loses her legs, Cotillard is astonishing, as is Schoenaerts as a boxer who helps restore her sexual identity. Audiard's hypnotic film means to shake you, and does.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Visionary and haunting, Santa Sangre is a mixture of blood poetry and gobbledygook that keeps springing astonishingly to life.
It's the ultimate in spoiler titles. And this stoner Ghostbusters, an altered state disguised as a movie, may also add up to a hot cult item if silliness doesn't sabotage the scares
A formula action movie that hits its formula marks as if no one expected more. I do expect more. So do Westlake fans. This Parker spits in our collective eye.

You know something is up when what looks like a cheapie fright flick is produced by Guillermo Del Toro and boasts an Oscar-nominated actress in Jessica Chastain. Mama doesn't live up to their potential, but the film knows how to creep you out.
Another January dud. Broken City drops hot-shot actors in a quicksand of clichés and watches them sink.
Hoffman uses all he's learned as a virtuoso actor to shape a film of flesh-and-blood characters, flushed with humor and tenderness.
In his screenwriting debut, Glee's gifted Chris Colfer, 22, proves he can lace a line with sass and soul.
Gangster Squad [is] a mob epic that flushes a classy cast (Sean Penn, Josh Brolin, Ryan Gosling, Emma Stone) down the sinkhole of creative bankruptcy.
Promised Land is a potent and powerful look at how the stressed economy is stressing farm communities across America. Director Gus Van Sant finds the human side of a knotty issue.
No one expects gutsy filmmaking in a musical. But that's just what King's Speech Oscar winner Tom Hooper delivers in Les Misérables. Damn the imperfections, it's perfectly marvelous.
Butter wishes it were a Christopher Guest sendup but comes off like a cheap imitation.
Chase offers a gritty, graceful salute to rock & roll in his ardent, acutely observed debut that makes him, at 67, a filmmaker to watch.
The film is a remarkable visual achievement, made more affecting by the depth the actors bring to their characters.
A dash of Tarantino might have juiced up Walter Salles' wrongheadedly well-mannered take on Jack Kerouac's 1957 Beat Generation landmark. On the Road feels tight and constricted.
This is Cruise's show. And he nails it. The patented smile is gone, replaced by a glower that makes Jack Reacher a dark and dazzling ride into a new kind of hell.
The knockout punch of the movie season is being delivered by Zero Dark Thirty. Chastain is a marvel, and Bigelow and Boal top their Oscar-winning work in The Hurt Locker.
The title is french for love. The movie itself, indisputably the year's best foreign-language film and an Oscar front-runner, defines what love is. And it does it the hard way.
Tarantino lives to cross the line. Is Django Unchained too much? ... It wouldn't be Tarantino otherwise.
Part One of director Peter Jackson's planned film trilogy of J.R.R. Tolkien's The Hobbit forces audiences to run an obstacle course before the fun kicks in.
A holiday-themed piece shot through with humor and heartbreak. No bull. And low on sappy.
The acting is aces, especially Pitt mixing it up with the superb James Gandolfini, as an assassin losing his game to hooch and hookers. They make this movie a potently nasty provocation.
Judd Apatow makes comedies that count. This Is 40 doesn't build to a catharsis. Yet Pete and Debbie's sparring yields some of Apatow's most personal observations yet.
This may be the longest 90 minutes you ever spend in a theater. You've been warned.
I got a goofball kick out of Pitch Perfect. Anna Kendrick is terrific in this spoofy, sassy romp. And I have one word for Rebel Wilson - Wow!
End of Watch gives you the savage whoosh of being on a job that can get you killed.
Searching for Sugar Man is a fresh and unexpected documentary that plays like a nail-biting mystery and a ticket to ride the whirlwind where art and commerce do battle.
Don't look for sweet and embraceable. This movie is not afraid to show its claws. Like the spirited teamwork of Kazan and Dano, Ruby Sparks is honest, deep and true.
As a sadistic dallas cop who moonlights as a hit man, Matthew McConaughey is on fire in Killer Joe, fierce and ferociously funny.
Potent and provocative, The Dark Knight Rises is the King Daddy of summer movie epics.
This true story plays like a gripping psychological thriller, offering hard speculation and harder truths. You won't be able to get it out of your head.

I don't really see why the Spidey reboot was needed right now, but The Amazing Spider-Man has its virtues. Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone are stellar and director Marc Webb has crafted a Spider-Man that touches the heart.
Journeys, shot on the last two nights of Young's 2011 solo world tour, is essential Neil Young.
People Like us is saved from melodramatic quicksand by live-wire acting from a touchingly vulnerable Chris Pine and a heartbreakingly good Elizabeth Banks. We believe we are watching people like us.
Being stoned or otherwise buzzed might help.
Seth MacFarlane's debut as a feature director hits all the sweet spots that irritate prudes. Ted is hysterically, gut-bustingly funny.
Beasts of the Southern Wild is a game-changer that gets you excited about movies again. Star Quvenzhané Wallis is a flat-out amazement.
To Rome With Love lacks the overarching theme of time and regret that distinguished Allen's last romantic comedy, but it has pleasures galore.
Carell and Knightley give it their bittersweet best. But I never rooted for them as a couple. And in a romance, even one with tragic notes, that really is the end of the world.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Brave is a rousing, gorgeously animated good time.
The acrobatic repetition bores you breathless. Spare Benjamin Walker, who deserves to go on to better things. But the movie deserves a stake through the heart.
A trio of superb performances guide a plot that pivots on secrets and lies before they fester. Your Sister's Sister works its way into your head until you can't stop thinking about it.
There's no denying the party-time pow of Rock of Ages, or of Tom Cruise's performance.
With that cast, we rightfully expect fireworks. What we get is the film equivalent of a wet blanket.
Sometimes a movie comes out of nowhere and wins you over. Safety Not Guaranteed is that kind of unexpected gift.
What should have been at least Ghostbusters lite ends up sliming audiences with sloppy seconds.
The Total Recall reboot is a futuristic fiasco, two hours you'll never get back - and every minute is a bad memory.
Celeste and Jesse Forever rises above the rom-com herd with breakout star performances from Jones and Samberg and a willingness to replace clichés with painful truths.
The Bourne Legacy is dwarfed by the three smash Bourne movies that preceded it. But for summer movie night escapsim, you could do worse.

Perks deserves points for going beyond the typical coming-of-age drivel aimed at teens. Logan Lerman excels as Charlie and Emma Watson makes a dream girl to die for, but the movie is stolen, head to tail, by Ezra Miller.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The plot couldn't be more cornball. Still, there's no denying the connection Eastwood makes with Adams.
Richard Gere's performance in the sinfully entertaining Arbitrage is too good to ignore. At 62, he is at the peak of his powers.
Elizabeth Olsen is beguiling in Liberal Arts, and Josh Radnor has a true filmmaker's eye for detail and atmosphere.
I believe in the church of Paul Thomas Anderson. Fierce and ferociously funny, The Master is a great movie, the best of the year so far, and a new American classic.
Dunst, Caplan and Fisher make a delicious trio as they stir up a bitches' brew of revenge against poor Becky (Wilson). Headland can write zingers that would make the cruelest bridezilla blush.
With a dynamite cast, an iconic screenwriter in rocker Nick Cave and an Aussie director in John Hillcoat, you assume a new classic. What you get is an ambitious try.
In a rare instance of truth in advertising, this movie actually is a good time.
Keanu Reeves is an astute and witty interviewer in Chris Kenneally's vital film. No true movie junkie is going to want to miss Side by Side.
However long it takes to get your bearings, Looper is worth it. Bruce Willis expertly blends tough and tender and Joseph Gordon-Levitt is at the top of his game in this rip-roaring mind-bender.
The trouble with Hit & Run is that it can't sustain its trippy effervescence. Despite a few scrappy twists and turns, it's ultimately a dead end.
I wanted to like this movie. Really. But this sequel doesn't wear down your resistance; it just wears you out.
Whitney Houston deserved better than to go out onscreen with this botch job remake of a 1976 soap opera that never deserved another thought.
It's not just Pixar that kicks ass in animation. There's magic in ParaNorman, a small miracle in stop-motion 3D from the wizards at Laika.

If you can get past the psychological density of the source material and the tabloid noise around the star , this mesmerizing mind-bender ought to prove that Robert Pattinson really can act and Director David Cronenberg never runs from a challenge.
Frank Langella gives a master class in acting in a movie with bracing humor and a dash of heartbreak - just don't expect to be wrapped up in a warm and fuzzy cinematic blanket.
Compliance is torture to sit through. It's also indispensable filmmaking. This fact-based movie is going to present you with questions that will haunt you long after you leave the theater.
Julie Delpy is boundlessly appealing. And Chris Rock is acerbic fun. But the frenzied cross-cultural gags take the piss out of the real subject: how blood ties can turn love into a battlefield.

What could have been strained farce or, worse, geezer porn, morphs instead into a film of hilarious and heartfelt pleasures. It helps that director David Frankel has two of the best actors on the planet to raise the game.
Ferrell and Galifianakis will crack you up - guaranteed. Is it too much to expect more?

Hollywood has been trying to pull off the bike messenger as action hero since 1986's Quicksilver with Kevin Bacon. You have to hand it to Premium Rush, which has the kinetic whoosh to keep you spinning.
Warm Bodies even suggests that true love can help the right zombie grow a new heart. That's a con job that makes Bodies lukewarm at best.
In his directing debut, Dave Grohl shows the instincts of a real filmmaker. Sound City hits you like a shot in the heart.
Sylvester Stallone shoots people in the face. That's it for subtext in this formula action swill. Why do I sound like I should expect more. Because the credits list the director as Walter Hill.
Willis gleefully strips down the action movie to a pretend game for children who like to fire guns and shoot bad guys. Machismo may never be the same.
There are only two reasons to see The Heat. But they are formidable reasons, and they go by the names of Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy.
The Way Way Back gets it wittily, thrillingly right. It turns the familiar into something bracingly fresh and funny. It makes you laugh, then breaks your heart.

Co-directors Chris Renaud and Pierre Coffin, who do Minion voices expertly, never let up on the laughs. A fart joke in 3-D may not be three times as wacky, but the high spirits of Despicable Me 2 are irresistible fun.
Your expectations of how bad The Lone Ranger is can't trump the reality.
On film, Bonfire achieves a consistency of ineptitude rare even in this era of over-inflated cinematic air bags.

Patinkin's performance is especially touching. He can say, "My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die" -- and make you laugh, cry and cheer at the same time. The movie, two hours of pure enchantment, has the same effect.
White House Down, rated PG-13 but as crass and cynical as a Michael Bay movie, is a depressing experience. A manufactured hit that plays to the basest instincts of its audience.
Just sign on for the trip. Back to the Future offers the summer's most dazzling joyride.
In the film, a comment is made about the power of a voice being not in technique but in the journey it took to get there. Stamp and Redgrave and living embodiments of that philosophy.
It's all infectious fun, despite the lack of originality. In the art of tickling funny bones, Crystal and Goodman earn straight A's.
World War Z is still as smart, shifty and scary as a starving zombie ready to chow down on you, baby, you.
It could have been one of those ripped-from-the-headlines quickies you see on subpar cable. Instead, The Bling Ring plugs into the zeitgeist of trash culture and sparks like a live wire.
Why should you see a documentary about backup singers? One look at the electrifying 20 Feet From Stardom and you'll have the answer, that is, after you stop cheering.
Man of Steel is a bumpy ride for sure. But there's no way to stay blind to its wonders.
This Is the End is the bust-out, badass comedy of the summer. And then some. It's so good you'll think you hallucinated it.
[Tiger Eyes has] an uncommon intimacy, the kind you find in a Judy Blume novel. Her grit and grace are all over this heartfelt adventure of a movie. She gives it a spirit that soars.
Whedon, without skimping on the tale's tragic undercurrents, has crafted an irresistible blend of mirth and malice.
Too bad the film devolves into a series of home-invasion clichés. The Purge was almost on to something.
Pacific Rim, thank the gods of cinema, is the work of a humanist ready to banish cynicism for compassion.
Fruitvale Station is a gut punch of a movie. By standing in solidarity with Oscar, it becomes an unstoppable cinematic force.
[This] trippy comic odyssey may not be for everyone. But Crystal Fairy gives off fumes that deliver a indisputable high.
It scared the living crap out of me. Only at the movies is that a compliment. So kudos to The Conjuring for putting fresh fire into the overworked haunted-house genre.
Jobs is a one-man show that needed to go for broke and doesn't. My guess is that Jobs would give it a swat.
Ain't Them Bodies Saints offers no glib answers or smooth resolution, but there's no question that Lowery is a filmmaker with a striking future.
There's no denying the stumbles that mar this alternately riveting and risible historical epic. Yet Lee Daniels' The Butler holds you, provokes you and ultimately moves you.
Elysium delivers sci-fi without dumbing it down. It's a hell-raiser with a social conscience.
Amanda Seyfried looks ripe to take on the life of Linda Lovelace, the Deep Throat blow-job queen who made porn accessible to 1970s America.
I really meant to at least like 2 Guns. But I couldn't. The movie just didn't make the extra effort.
James Ponsoldt's funny and touching coming-of-age tale covers old ground with disarming freshness... By taking it slow, The Spectacular Now takes a piece out of you.
If the subtext of this misbegotten parade of lame shock tactics is the death of cinema, then The Canyons certainly knows how to nail the coffin shut.
Oooowee, here is one scorchingly sexy movie.
The Internship takes a padded two hours to tell a thin story that buries its charm in emo-mongering and Google plugs.
Putting heart and heat into a film that could have easily slid by on silliness, Cleese proves himself a master actor.
So much for the theory that sequels never equal the original.
Your eyeballs have no choice but to go boinnnnng.
For dynamite suspense loaded with thrills and wicked fun, you can't beat The Fugitive.

Director Ivan Reitman keeps the Aykroyd-Ramis screenplay zipping right along, creating something like Abbott & Costello Meet the Exorcist. Aykroyd and Murray make the perfect summer tonic for raising spirits.
Does Carey go too far? Duh. But why gripe when you can't stop laughing?

Hugh Jackman, in his sixth time up as Wolverine, still has the juice. This pissed-off man of Adamantium claws is stalking new ground (Japan), and his fight with yakuza on top of Tokyo's speeding bullet train is a wowser.
Want to see great acting, from comic to tragic and every electrifying stop in between? See Cate Blanchett in Blue Jasmine.
Meet a theme-park phenom in the form of the killer whales (orcas in the trade) on view in Gabriela Cowperthwaite's gripping mindbender of a documentary.

Where Drive shrewdly mystifies, Only God Forgives stupefies. You can see its gears grinding. But I'll always hang on for a rare talent like Refn. Even when he stumbles, he leaves you eager to see what he's up to next.
Brace yourself for a movie joyride that sends you home reeling from thrills, laughter and the pleasure of honest sentiment.
After Earth merits comparison with 2000's Battlefield Earth, John Travolta's godawful film tribute to the sci-fi novel by Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard. Yes, it's that bad.
Eco-terrorism drives the plot of The East, but this propulsive thriller is laced with a humanism that trumps any political agenda.
It takes a certain dark magic to make the talent of a top cast disappear right before your eyes. Now You See Me does just that.
The Host is born from the mother of all things Twilight, Stephenie Meyer, which is the next best - or worst - thing, depending on your point of view.
[The Place Beyond The Pines] a beast of a movie, an emotional roller coaster that threatens to go off the rails, and does.
Want a bracing alternative to the usual Hollywood swill? Try Gimme the Loot, a fresh, funky jolt of filmmaking joy.
You could call it an Aussie Dreamgirls. I'd call it a blast of joy and music that struts right into your heart.
I'd see Tina Fey and Paul Rudd in anything, but this is pushing it. Admission is so slight that a breeze could flatten it.
Spring Breakers, beach-party fluff done as an art film by the reliably bizarre Harmony Korine, is a return to form for Franco.
Magicians have been pulling rabbits out of hats for ages. And yet, with all this talent, no one can make a decent script materialize.
... as limitless technology teaches the wizard about his own human limitations, Franco hits grace notes that let us see glimmers of how great and powerful this uneven Oz might have been.
The effort to put a personal face on the major issue of occupation is as timely as Iraq and Afghanistan, but the execution is clumsy and cliché-ridden.
Ascher's unique and unforgettable film is a tribute to movie love. I couldn't have liked it more.
What seems like the makings of a tawdry horror show becomes a subtle and moving exploration into the sacred and profane.
Jack the Giant Slayer proves the axiom "If you can't make it good, make it 3D."
Costner tells a personal story that never loses touch with the vast Western spaces encompassing and defining it. Dances With Wolves is an epic that breathes. And it's a beauty.
Nominated by the Academy as the year's best foreign-language film, No grabs you hard, no mercy, and keeps you riveted.
I hate Safe Haven. It's a terrible thing to do to your Valentine.

As supernatural types, Oscar winners Jeremy Irons and Emma Thompson overact so strenuously and with such outrageously awful Southern accents that you fear the damage this crock may do to their reputations.
This series needs to die here. That would be something to "Yippee Ki-Yay" about.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Side Effects is a hell of a thriller, twisty, terrific and packed with surprises you don't see coming.
The Gatekeepers cuts deeper than any political thriller. It's a powerhouse.

Some actors don't need top-shelf material. Just the pleasure of their company is enough. And so Al Pacino, Christopher Walken and Alan Arkin turn the insubstantial Stand Up Guys into solid entertainment.

Park has built a hothouse of erotic tension that's primed to explode. Some will find it too much. Screw them. Park's goal is to bust form, not conform to it. Take Stoker for what it is: a thriller of savage beauty.
The ending isn't squishy scary or deeply satisfying. Bummer. Otherwise, Prometheus kicks ass so hard and often that it's impossible not to be thrilled by it.
Danny Boyle's trippy, Inception-like thriller is a hypnotic head trip that demands you trust no one.
At the top of a new baseball season, it's hard not to root for a movie that's in it for the love of the game.
Nothing classic here, except the vehicles. But if you're looking for revved-up cars, trucks, tanks and tunnel racing, F&F6 is King Kong on wheels.
The first movie left you with an exhilarating rush. All that Part III leaves is, well, a hangover.
From first scene to last, Hawke and Delpy shine brilliantly, wearing their roles like second skins.
It's always painful when a brilliant book becomes a bust of a movie.
Abrams boldly goes into Star Trek Into Darkness, and crushes it again. It's more fun and more intense, without giving less to the characters.
It's impossible not to fall hard for Greta Gerwig, who wrote the script with Baumbach and plays Frances with such smart, rumpled radiance that you bask in her glow.
There may be worse movies this summer than The Great Gatsby, but there won't be a more crushing disappointment.
Don't let anyone spoil the surprises that unravel in this movie as Polley has her brilliant way with the elusiveness of truth.
Jeff's accidental drowning death in 1997, at 30, underscores the sense of loss in a heartfelt and deeply moving film. It'll get to you.
Drawing skillfully on a first-rate cast, Redford builds a riveting, resonant political thriller that values the complexity of its characters and the intelligence of its audience.
But for all the clanking armies of iron knights on display to dazzle the eager kid in each of us, this summer epic rings hollow. There's no one home inside the suit.

Directors Scott McGehee and David Siegel, abetted by an astute scriptfrom Nancy Doyne and Carroll Cartwright, find something sadly timeless in a child torn apart in a custody battle that no one wins, least of all the child.
In between scenes of the muscleheads torturing their victim, Bay indulges his taste for treating women as sluts and grisly brutality as a nifty excuse for a cheap laugh.
It's a towering achievement that grows more riveting and resonant with the years.
Bahrani is a gifted filmmaker. But he shoots himself in the foot by throwing in a contrived plot device that creates drama at the expense of credibility.
What you do need to know is that the acting is top-tier all the way. McConaughey, on a career roll, is magnificent.
For all the bells and whistles - an electronic score by M83, a screen-busting Imax presentation and Cruise going full throttle - Oblivion feels arid and antiseptic, untouched by human hands.
It's a mind-blower.
Film genius to miss the mark. Case in point: Terrence Malick's To the Wonder, a beautifully empty exercise that - so glacial is the pace - makes Malick's Tree of Life look like G.I. Joe: Retaliation.
How a new director works with actors is telling, and the performances in Disconnect are first-rate all the way.
You don't have to be in vogue to enjoy this stylish ride through Bergdorf's. It's a surprise package to die for.
Snow White and the Huntsman has a darkness that seeps into the soul - but it's also definitely a missed opportunity. Director Rupert Sanders loses his nerve just when the story starts cooking.
The first part of the film is raunchy fun, but Magic Mike slowly degenerates into a simplistic cautionary fable.
The hilarious and heartfelt Moonrise Kingdom is a consistent pleasure. By evoking the joys and terrors of childhood, it reminds us how to be alive.
Another body-switching comedy? Seriously?
Evan Glodell's explosive debut feature is a thing of toxic beauty.
Rise of the Planet of the Apes rises and, at times, even soars - all thanks to what human actors in league with computer technology can now achieve to bring the apes to life.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a breakthrough star performance from a terrific actor, Dominic Cooper, getting a chance to let it rip. Just don't expect a docudrama.
This movie wants and needs to come at you like a beast in the dark. Allow it.
The mash-up of cowboys and aliens doesn't do either camp any favors. How are we supposed to work up a rooting interest when both sides are shooting blanks?
It's a pleasure to come across the sharply funny and touching Crazy Stupid Love. It's a live one with a dream cast that keeps springing playful surprises.
Another Earth offers imagination and provocation to spare.
Despite a pair of livewires in the leads, Friends With Benefits is just not enough.

Evans, who played the Human Torch in two less-than-fantastic Fantastic Four films, brings such humor, heart and vigor to virtuous Steve that our rooting interest holds even when the action gets to be standard-issue.
It's a pleasure to sink into an animated family movie from Disney that radiates charm with a gentleness that seems damn near revolutionary.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2 puts a triumphant capper on a decade of Pottermania.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Larry Crowne is more than a missed opportunity. It's alarmingly, depressingly out of touch.
Here's a hit-and-miss farce that leaves you wishing it was funnier than it is. Why? Because it wussies out on a sharp premise. Because it wastes a killer cast that's ready to rock it.
The dialogue is witty and spiked with delicious malice. At least it is when Pierce delivers it. It won't spoil the plot to say that he is pricelessly good at taking you places you don't see coming.
Watching Transformers: Dark of the Moon makes you die a little inside. Is this the future of movies? God help us! Michael Bay, you've done it again.
On the surface, the film seems like one of those docudramas that beg to be rewarded solely for their good intentions. But Chris Weitz cuts deep. This movie will get under your skin.
Cameron Diaz's fem spin on Billy Bob Thornton's Bad Santa should have added up to raunchy fun. Sadly, it only took about 10 minutes to wipe the smile off my face.
I blow a piston whenever 2006's Cars gets trashed as the runt of the Pixar litter. The sequel is a tire-burning burst of action and fun with a beating heart under its hood.
The film swings from melodrama to sermonizing, both blunting the human drama that needs to come to the fore. Weisz holds the ground in a performance of ferocity and feeling.
The Help is an exhilarating gift, a deeply touching human story filled with humor and heartbreak, and sublime performances from Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, Emma Stone and Co.
Final Destination 5 starts with an R-rated 3D bang, but the cheap thrills wear off way fast, and we're left with atrocious acting, feeble writing and clueless directing.
30 Minutes or Less is all about the zigzagging rush of the ride.
The Ides of March is a pulse-racing thriller that hits where it hurts. Clooney's performance is exceptional and Gosling is terrific in an all-stops-out role.
Michael Shannon gives himself over completely to a complex role and leaves you shattered. Director Jeff Nichols throws curveballs, but his film is unique and unforgettable.
Refusing to hide from pain or bow to it, 50/50 makes its own rules. Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Seth Rogen are a dream team.
The fun of Killer Elite, such as it is, is all in the hardass action. But there's nothing elite about this disposable time-killer.
Moneyball is one of the best and most viscerally exciting films of the year.
Quote not available.
Van Sant and his longtime cinematographer, Harris Savides, can caress the faces of youth with a poet's eye for beauty and pain.
Lurie wants us to see the moral wounds that come from losing control, a solid reason for a remake. Both takes on Straw Dogs hold up a dark mirror to humanity. Choose your own bad medicine.
Director Gavin O'Connor comes out swinging in this flawed but fiercely moving family drama...Strong stuff.
For those of us who read - on smudgy paper or a battery-powered screen - Page One is a vital, indispensable hell-raiser.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Buckle up for the existential bloodbath of Drive, a brilliant piece of business that races on a B-movie track until it switches to the dizzying fuel of undiluted creativity.
A Nazi-hunting thriller deepens into a meditation on conscience in The Debt, a movie that holds you in its grip.
The film never takes hold emotionally, despite strong work from Holmes and young Madison. With Del Toro's name in the credits, standard chills aren't enough.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: High praise for Vera Farmiga, a stunner of an actress, who makes her directing debut with the same bold instincts for sharp humor and harsh truths that mark her performances.
Our Idiot Brother comes off as a blueprint for a smart script no one really made.
Voilà! Black magic.
Quote not available.
John Sayles, a filmmaker by trade, a provocateur by nature, means to stir things up with Amigo. That he does, and more power to him.
This tear-jerking twaddle, adapted by David Nicholls from his 2009 bestseller, is nearly as bad as Anne Hathaway's British accent, which is heading for infamy.
I'm calling bullsh** on this 3D concert movie. The movie plays like an evangelical prayer meeting, though I'd hold the hallelujahs.
What I see in The Intouchables is a tasty bonbon spiked with mirth but light on malice. Omar Sy and François Cluzet are superb actors.
The tear-jerking in Real Steel is as shameless as its product placement. We're being hustled.
Green Lantern is a new primer on how not to make a comicbook movie unless you want to screw shit up. Flat FX, smirky acting, clunky writing and clueless direction. WTF?
Out of a premise horrifically familiar from tragedies at Columbine and Virginia Tech director Shawn Ku has crafted a film that will haunt you for a good long time.
Hanna is a fairy tale of lightning speed, gritty action and shocking gravity, all driven by the electronic beat of a hypnotic score by the Chemical Brothers.

The comic mojo of Danny McBride can be a thing of fucked-up beauty. So I was stoked that McBride signed on as star and co-writer of Your Highness. But the air goes out of that balloon pretty damn quick.
The limp-d--- remake of 1981's Arthur - starring Russell Brand in the happy-drunk role indelibly created by Dudley Moore - sounds promising, but it ends in disaster.
Here's a better-than-average spook house movie, mostly because Insidious decides it can haunt an audience without spraying it with blood.
Despite detours into sentiment and preaching, In a Better World is an emotional powerhouse.
Think of Groundhog Day morphing from comedy to thriller and you'll get an idea of the mischief afoot in Source Code.

What can you say about an HBO miniseries adapted from a 1941 novel that follows the rise and fall of an independent woman during the Great Depression? Let's try "perfection," which is what director Todd Haynes achieves in his loyal, lyrical adaptation.
Writer-director John Gray digs into his own background to create the ardent and atmospheric White Irish Drinkers. The close, cramped intimacy of this film is so real it stings.
Looks aren't everything. Case in point: Sucker Punch, a dazzling visual design that goes tone-deaf every time it opens its dumb mouth or makes claims to profundity.
This is rock-solid entertainment. McConaughey, a cunning mesmerizer in the courtroom, steers this Lincoln into what could be a hell-raising franchise.
Limitless hits you like an adrenaline rush that will have you saying, "I'll have what he's having."
'Paul' is more a bagful of giggles. Rogen is a nonstop hoot, but it's the byplay between Frost and Pegg that roots the laughs in characters we care about.
Quote not available.
This movie wins you over, head and heart, without cheating. It's just about perfect.
Cary Joji Fukunaga has reanimated a classic for a new generation, letting 'Jane Eyre' resonate with terror and tenderness.
Seeing the plot of 'Twilight' get stuffed into Little Red's riding hood is a painful business. But look for a fat box office.
'Take Me Home Tonight' has just enough heart and retro party spirit to hold the line before familiarity breeds contempt.
'The Adjustment Bureau' misses by a mile. Despite heroic efforts by Damon and the lovely Blunt to build a plausible love story, the movie dissolves into silliness.
Say what you will about 'Rango,' the computer-animated Western riding hard on Johnny Depp doing the voice of a lizard - just don't call it business as usual.
Kelly Reichardt has crafted a haunted dream of a movie to get lost in.
Between a diabolically funny start and a surprise climax, Scream 4 offers nothing more than a series of gory deaths that grow tiresome with repetition.
As the film's director, Robert Redford eases with hypnotic skill into this tale of justice in the aftermath of Abraham Lincoln's assassination.
Ayn Rand's monumental 1,168-page, 1957 novel gets the low-budget, no-talent treatment and sits there flapping on screen like a bludgeoned seal.
Delicate business is being transacted in this touchingly personal and altogether extraordinary film from writer-director Mike Mills. Beginners is one from the bruised heart.
Richard Ayoade, the British comic making a remarkable feature debut with his adaptation of Joe Dunthorne's 2008 novel, blends mirth and malice with deadpan brilliance.
A potent reminder of what jazzed us about Bryan Singer's first two X-Men and the Marvel comics that spawned them.
'Tree' delivers truths that don't go down easy. No one with a genuine interest in the potential of film would think of missing it.
Somebody must have roofied me. I left The Hangover Part II feeling dazed and abused, wondering how bad things happened to such a good comedy.
Marshall deserves props for putting the "show" back into the Pirates business. But face it, he's polishing a giant turd.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As a filmmaker, Allen has grappled with the temptations of repeating himself instead of forging a fresh path. You can feel that conflict here, and watching him work it out is exhilarating.
Will Ferrell delivers a performance of implosive intensity that rings true in every detail.
As played by the spectacular Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Hesher is the id run rampant. Even when the script edges him into Hallmark sentiment, you can't take your eyes off him.
A retro monster mash with a child's heart, a prodigy's unstoppable imagination and FX dazzle to spare.
Kristen Wiig is an indisputable goddess of comedy. This rowdy fem-friendship movie she stars in and wrote with Annie Mumolo is infused with the Wiig brand of wicked mischief.
Hemsworth, an Aussie actor with a vocal command to match his heaving brawn, doesn't just play the role, he owns it.
The half-star rating goes to John Krasinski for heroically rising above this vile dung heap of a movie.
What's not to like?
'Prom,' directed with too bland a TV hand by Joe Nussbaum, evaporates as you watch it, but it does go down easy.
'Fast Five' will push all your action buttons, and some you haven't thought of. So what if you hate yourself in the morning.
Rio is a brightly-colored, dizzying pinwheel of 3D animation in which nothing much happens. Sounds like summer is here early.
Incendies is a devastating mystery thriller from Quebec filmmaker Denis Villeneuve that grabs you hard and won't let go.
Spurlock says he's not selling out, he's buying in. I'm buying into Spurlock. As ever, he makes you laugh till it hurts.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Even nonreaders of the book can figure out what happens next. It's all in the telling. Sara Gruen provided grit and pungent detail. The movie settles for gloss.
If you can get past your feelings for the troubled Gibson, you get to watch a high-wire performance of the highest caliber.
Open yourself up to this thoughtful, moving personal adventure and you're in for a uniquely memorable experience.
All this germ procedural offers is the sight of people behaving badly, willing to do their worst to get first dibs on a vaccine. Sadly, that's no surprise.
Footloose 2011 is harmless as far as it goes, but on the dance floor and off it never goes nearly far enough.
The Hunger Games has epic spectacle, yearning romance, suspense that won't quit and a shining star in Jennifer Lawrence.
Credit Pickering's deft script for avoiding the usual clichéd speed bumps, though sex and lies are on the menu.
This bracing new take on 21 Jump Street has a playful spark all its own. It's a blast.
The funny, touching and vital Jeff, Who Lives at Home reaffirms your faith in Jay and Mark Duplass. Their films hit you where you live.
Detachment gets to you. It hits hard.
Ferrell is an hombre loco. Mi gusta.
Paranormal Activity has been here before, of course, but Silent House springs tangy new tricks, and Olsen is a primo scream queen.
Westfeldt is the pulse of Friends With Kids, presenting us with life in all of its vibrant, messy sprawl.
The film is in black-and-white so the gore doesn't spray quite as colorfully. But you'll still puke up a storm.
