The movie has all the heft of a tweet, but Philips has made it look pimp and, until the police end the party, Project X really is a riot.
It lies there flapping like a dying fish. Skip it.
I don't know what to make of Act of Valor. It's like reviewing a recruiting poster.
Paul Rudd is the best friend a movie comedy can have.
One look at the dreadful mess that is Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance will turn your whisper into a primal Cage scream: MAKE THIS MOVIE STOP!
A trio of appealing actors is trapped in an action-spiked romcom death-sentenced by a lack of humor, heart and a coherent reason for being.
Director Madonna's tenacity deserves praise, unlike anything else in this torturously torpid costume drama, except the costumes which gleam with period elegance.
The Woman in Black doesn't break new ground, but in its suggestions of fine film ghost stories, it works you over with riveting restraint.
The potent and provocative journey in Chronicle never stops springing surprises. You'll be hooked.
Everything in One for the Money rings cringingly false.
In the face of Weisz's magnificence, it's impossible to dismiss The Deep Blue Sea as dated and creaky. Weisz makes it timeless.
This feeble followup to 2010's godawful Clash of the Titans sucketh the mighty big one.
Who wants to see a fairy tale that weighs a ton? Mirror Mirror reflects badly on everyone involved.
The best social documents on film do more than show you what's wrong in the world - they make it personal. Bully does that with a passion.
The unexpected spark between Smith and Brolin makes MiB3 primo summer fun.
The still-born What To Expect... is an all-star dud that could be easily confused with Valentine's Day and New Year's Eve, except for the absence of Ashton Kutcher.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Battleship is all noise and crashing metal, sinking to the shallows of Michael Bay's Armageddon and then digging to the brain-extinction level of the Transformers trilogy.
The Dictator starts at outrageous and rockets on from there. Screw the occasional sputter.
Powered by Paul Simon's brilliance, Under African Skies is a cultural lightning bolt that soars on its music and an unshakable belief in the transcendence of art.
Burton's visuals are a sumptuous treat, as is Depp's unerring sense of mischief - but, after a fierce and funny start, Dark Shadows simply spins its wheels.
Quote not available.
With a lesser cast, the movie would be a lineup of TV-movie clichés. But this is a cast that never makes a false move even when the script settles for formula.
All hail Joss Whedon, the warrior king of this dizzying, dazzling 3D action epic. The Avengers is Transformers with a brain, a heart and a working sense of humor.
Hold on tight. It's a true call of the wild.
Quote not available.
The dream partnership of Jason Segel and Nick Stoller gets dinged a bit in the frustratingly uneven The Five-Year Engagement. Luckily, the movie never runs on sitcom empty.
As played by Jack Black, in an award-caliber performance, Bernie is everything you'd want in a friend. The movie is a one-of-a-kind inspiration.
The Lucky One doesn't have a genuine emotion in it or a plausible reason to endure it. It's strictly for the sisters of the cult of Sparks and the men who love them.
For the Farrellys, The Three Stooges is a labor of love. For non-believers, it's merely a labor.
If it's true that you always kill the thing you love, then horror honchos Joss Whedon and Drew Goddard have taken an ax to slasher cinema in The Cabin in the Woods and chopped it up for kindling.
American Reunion reminds us what we liked about the original: the way the movie sweetened its raunch to build a rooting interest in these characters.
Damsels in Distress is an exhilarating gift of a comedy.
How is Titanic in 3D? The answer is pretty damn dazzling.
Quote not available.
The trouble with Safe is that you know where it's going every step of the way.
Quote not available.

McGregor and Blunt have charm to spare and the no-bull instinct to cut to the heart of a scene. In the Dead Sea of Hollywood formula, their film is a distinct delight, brimming over with spirit and surprise.
Haywire comes close to achieving Soderbergh's goal of creating "a Pam Grier movie made by Alfred Hitchcock."
It took a toll on Marilyn Monroe to look effortlessly buoyant on camera. Michelle Williams lets us see why. It's a great, soulful performance. Sit back and behold.
Hugo emerges as a spectacular adventure for film lovers of all ages.
The challenge Disney has with The Muppets is to show a new generation what the fuss was all about. Slam-dunk. The movie slaps a smile on your face you won't want to wipe off.
The Artist encapsulates everything we go to movies for: action, laughs, tears and a chance to get lost in another world. How can Oscar resist?
The sexless, bloodless, padded and plodding Breaking Dawn, Part 1 is the worst Twilight movie to date.
The Descendants is damn near perfect. Director Alexander Payne is a master of the human comedy and George Clooney has never exposed himself to the camera this openly.
Melancholia is a potent beauty of a film, and Kirsten Dunst gives an incomparable performance.
Jack and Jill is total bust, a stupefyingly unfunny and shamelessly lazy farce packed with cringe-worthy jokes and overt product placement.
Despite being buried in layers of prosthetic latex, DiCaprio is a roaring wonder as J. Edgar Hoover. Even when the film trips on its tall ambitions, you can't shake it off.
Purists may holler that Fiennes and screenwriter John Logan have cut the Bard's second-longest play into two tense hours onscreen, but the power of the piece is undeniable.
You won't remember Tower Heist an hour later, but the top cast makes the jokes (even the lousy ones) go down easy.
As the Bard probably would not say, Anonymous is some crazy shit.
At best diverting, at worst drearily conventional, The Rum Diary is pre-gonzo Thompson. But the seeds are there, ready to yield a harvest of fear and loathing.
Drake Doremus has crafted a crazily inventive and totally irresistible tale of first love that makes the familiar seem bittersweet and heart-stoppingly new.
Pretty cast. Potent premise. Piss-poor execution.
Elizabeth Olsen gives a sensational performance in a gripping psychological thriller, from gifted first-time writer-director Sean Durkin.
Margin Call is an explosive drama that speaks lucidly and scarily to the times we live in.
Anything for Halloween? I'd vouch for The Skin I Live In, a scary, sexy and terrifically twisted horror film from the artist known as Pedro Almodóvar.
One gut-busting death after another, terror giving way to tedium.
The actors give it their all, especially Knightley, whose jaw- jutting, heavily accented and unfairly criticized portrayal gives this erotic mind-bender its fighting spirit.
There's no easy way to shake off Shame. It gets in your head.
H&K are past their sell-by date. Way past.
Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy emerges as a tale of loneliness and desperation among men who can never disclose their secret hearts... It's easily one of the year's best films.
Acting doesn't get much better than the subtly brilliant display put on by Tilda Swinton in We Need to Talk About Kevin.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Director Garry Marshall follows last year's Valentine's Day with New Year's Eve where an all-star cast lines up to collect paychecks - at our expense!
Wahlberg could sleepwalk through this role, and does. See this movie and you'll surely follow his lead.
Lots of talented young singers decorate the scenery, notably Jeremy Jordan who has vocal and acting chops that shine even in this bucket of Glee Goes Gospel cornpone.
Miss Bala is a terrifying tale of a beauty contest that ends in horror... The film is a harrowing experience. It cuts deep.
Margaret comes apart at the seams as you watch it, but it gives off a lovely light. Seek it out. You can thank me later.
Jolie has a keen eye for the core of a scene and a true director's instinct for the pulse that defines character. Her live-wire movie is out to shake us.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film belongs right here... 'A Separation' is a landmark film. No way will you be able to get it out of your head.
The gifted Dee Rees makes finding out a stirring and heartfelt journey. And Adepero Oduye is unforgettable. A star is born.
As directed with grit and grace by Rodrigo García, this quietly devastating film goes bone-deep.
From the amateur acting, writing and directing to an ending that is shocking only in its stupidity, The Devil Inside will make you puke for all the wrong reasons.
Is there anything that Meryl Streep can't do as an actress? One can only marvel at her virtuoso performance as Britain's Margaret Thatcher in 'The Iron Lady.'
Solidly crafted, impeccably acted and self-important in the way that Oscar loves, 'Extremely Loud' is also incredibly close to exploitation.
There's a lot of fun waiting at We Bought a Zoo, but it's the feelings that run through every scene that'll make you glad you came.
The Adventures of Tintin comes at you in a whoosh, like a volcano full of creative ideas in full eruption... It hits home for the kid in all of us who wants to bust out and run free.
Fincher's Dragon Tattoo is a faithful adaptation that brings the dazzle but shortchanges on the daring... It's gloriously rendered but too impersonal to leave a mark.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: War Horse gets to you. It's one from the heart.
The film version of Carnage hasn't just lost God from its title, it's lost the laughs from the play that brought it life.
This is Cruise's show and the actor brings the role a startling athletic grace and becoming maturity. If someone asks you what a true movie star is, point to Cruise.
In an act of criminal negligence, Ritchie has wasted Robert Downey Jr. in a sequel that eliminates smarts in favor of relentless headbanging.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Patton Oswalt's dark duet with Charlize Theron is funny, touching and vital. But fair warning: The laughs in Young Adult leave bruises.
Mockingjay Part 2 is a fittingly dark end to the Hunger Games franchise, not as exciting perhaps as Catching Fire, but more politically charged.
Not messing too much with the formula or characters that made Peanuts famous, Blue Sky have played it very safe and pretty damn smart keeping most of the charm of Schulz's original work.
A wild ride with some noir-ish undertones, Zootropolis packs in plenty to keep the whole family entertained.

The cast and director Roar Uthaug all handle the material brilliantly, so it's a shame that the script is quite so slavish to generic formula. However, there is an excellent swerve in the dark to watch out for late in the game.
Indivisible could be depressing, and it certainly has moments of melodrama, but it is also life-affirming, hopeful and above all a touching story of sisterhood under strain.
Pete's Dragon is stuffed full of heart, wild emotion and an overflowing love of nature.

If this film is anything to go by, [Australians] are living with exactly the same racial tensions and dealing with the same level of ignorance as we are. But it's a lot bloody easier to laugh about it when it's 10,000 miles away.

There's no doubt that The Red Turtle is charming and enchanting, but it's muted tone, leisurely pace and jarring lack of dialogue in the last half make for a less emotive conclusion than the simple story could have earned.
While it's definitely not a tame film, Wild could certainly have done with being a little more controlled.
Goosebumps is no Gremlins, but for some of the running time it does have a bit of a classic '80s feel about it.
It might give some a hard-core headache, but Hardcore Henry is an ultra-violent blast of fresh air.

Steve Jobs is an impressive feat; it might not fulfill tech geeks' desires to see more of the machines, but it certainly makes the man behind Apple a fascinatingly flawed character who is tricky to love, but very easy to watch.
While Beasts of No Nation is far from easy viewing, it is powerful, urgent and heartbreaking filmmaking and a stark reminder of how boys become beasts in a war without end.
So nerve-shredding, it will make your whole body hurt.
(T)error slightly over-simplifies the idea of who is right and wrong by the end. Still, it's a riveting look below the surface of law enforcement.
With hints of both All the President's Men and Good Night and Good Luck, Truth steps in the footsteps of some brilliant films where journalists are the righteous heroes.
Sorrentino knows exactly where he's heading and through all the absurd splashes of humour, delivers an incredibly poignant and invigorating ending.
If you choose to accept The Invitation, you won't regret it.
Partisan is an impressive feature debut; both expertly condemning its paternalistic society, but sadly lacking in a single interesting female character to take a stand to Cassel's complex figure.
The Witch is expertly directed with a hysterical score, beautiful production design and wicked performances from its central cast.
With a highly flawed script full of completely unlikeable characters, Beeba Boys just repeatedly misses the mark.
Lively, but flawed.
Compelling, claustrophobic, cutting edge and clever, Ex Machina is as smart and satisfying as science fiction gets.
King Cobra isn't all fun and filth, but it could certainly be accused of promoting some pretty negative stereotypes.
A stark, but brilliant debut.
A Dark Song is magic for much of its running time, but much like its protagonist's willingness to have ceremonial sex with a madman, it loses the plot in its final scenes.
Observance implores you to continue watching, but doesn't quite fully reward its audience for doing so.

Despite its fantastical elements and occasionally obvious plot points, it is a film about emotional truths and an admirable attempt to inject some real heart and soul into a YA adaptation. And not even a love triangle in sight.

If the exasperating first half of this film based on the cutesy toy range is a chore to get through, it might just thaw some stone cold hearts by the time Justin Timberlake starts belting out tunes by the end.
It does go to some dark places and our heroine emerges as a yet another shining example of a feminist horror avenger, if not nearly as iconic as some that came before her.
While Strangled is an interesting, if highly disturbing story, it's let down a little by its script and style.
Three Billboards is a wonderfully tragic comedy that gifts McDormand with an incredible character.

Fuelled by superb performances, particularly from old-timer Trintignant and teen Fantine Harduin as Eve, the film truly finds a heart when it puts these two contrasting faces together in a scene.

Overall, Jailbreak is an impressive effort and will likely appeal to fans of the fight scenes in The Raid. Just don't expect to be as impressed by anything outside of the kinetic, expertly choreographed clashes.
Miike has his own wicked sense of humour and while there is plenty of stunning fight choreography; the real draw is Manji's relationship with the little girl.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For everyone else who has ever thought studying film would suck all the joy out of actually watching films, stay well clear.

Frequently funny but with an undercurrent of raw sadness, Last Flag Flying reminds again just how great a filmmaker Linklater is, and shows that he has an exciting career ahead documenting the years beyond the joys of youth.
While Pickups does have some interesting insights into the actor's process and the pressures of fame, its best in its most meta-moments but ultimately its ideas could have been summed up in a short.
Perhaps a little too cold and calculated, Thoroughbreds is dark, but lacking in real bite. A fairly impressive beast then, but not a race winner.
It's one of those films that needs to be seen to be believed. Dealing with desire and death, growing pains and inequality, Good Manners is truly unique and surprisingly touching come the finale.

Julia Jedlikowska is an excellent lead and shines as the determined teen. While her tale does meander, it is her experiences of first love that give Sicilian Ghost Story its hypnotic and tender heartbeat.

Ingrid Goes West is bright, funny as hell and so full of contemporary razor-sharp insight that it will make many in the audience squirm. Fuelled by Aubrey Plaza's hysterical performance, it's almost #perfect.
Allied wants to be a classic tale of war, deception and doomed love, but despite the calibre of all involved, it's simply a fitfully entertaining but oddly-plotted affair.
Orange Sunshine is a riveting documentary with an exciting, thought-provoking, tragic and hopeful story to tell. Sit back and enjoy the vibe.
Unfortunately, all Dog Eat Dog reveals is a group of talented people with their best work long behind them.
While perhaps serious in some of what it has to say about the pregnancy experience, as well as the state of the world we live in, Prevenge mostly sticks to dark laughs and does it well.

For every silly or sexist misstep, there's always a Shakespeare-quoting gangster round the next corner to slap a grin right back on your face. Mutafukaz is bound to be the coolest animation you'll see this year.
Despite its contemporary relevance, it's a shame this didn't dig deeper and tackle the more precise, pressing issues France (and the rest of Europe) faces today.
Dolan offers his cast no way of hiding, deploying a consistent set of stylistic techniques to enhance all these gut-wrenching performances.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It all boils down to the complicated relationships of fathers and sons, but with some riveting action and heart-tugging drama, Trespass Against Us ends up as thrilling must-see.
American Honey will frustrate some but as a time capsule and ode to youthful energy, it's priceless.
What could have been a sensationalist ripped-from-the-headlines expose of a disturbing relationship is handled tensely, but sensitively.

Unintelligible for new viewers, appropriate only for the superfan, and even then, an unsatisfying hit.

A remarkable film that deserves as much acclaim as Farhadi's award-winner.
Not only does it deal with sex in a straightforward manner, but it also deals with the equally sensitive themes of disability and religion, all of which writer/director Ben Lewin pulls off skilfully.

Situated in the middle of Ulrich Seidl's trilogy, it's hard to avoid the feeling that Paradise: Faith is the weakest film of the three, but it still has the kind of powerful and singular moments that few directors are capable of producing.
[It's] made with all of the visual élan we've come to expect, but the pacing is leaden and the film lacks a sense of purpose.
Mackenzie skilfully sketches the sense of community and hierarchy that prison life is built upon, and makes us keenly aware of the simmering aggression that threatens to boil over at any time.
When was the last time you saw an erotic thriller that worked simultaneously on both levels?
If you have ever taken a moment to wonder what a vampire romance directed by Jim Jarmusch would look like, then Only Lovers Left Alive probably comes pretty close to the film you imagined.
Her asks us to consider what constitutes a 'real' relationship in a world where every interaction is filtered through technology, making it feel like a vital contemporary romance.
An Oversimplification of Her Beauty is a love story, and it appropriately feels as if it has been made with the heart more than the head.
The relentless intensity quickly grows numbing.
This extraordinary work serves up a series of shocking and surreal sequences, and uses the artifice of filmmaking to expose horrendous truths.
A hilarious comedy and a thrilling action film. The General has it all.
The work of a young director reaching to impress without having fully formed ideas ...
The bold editing and imaginative cinematography impresses throughout, but it's the soundtrack that proves to be The Broken Circle Breakdown's biggest asset ...
A fascinating portrait of the revered cultural theorist from the great John Akomfrah.
The film has a haunting quality that allows it to linger in the mind, and leaves us with a sense that Lowery has great work in his future.
Tighter editing could have elevated this from a respectable adaptation into something with an incisive edge, but at least it's a better take on the book than the misguided 1996 version ...
The sensitivity and empathy with which Seidl explores the pangs of first love might catch many viewers off guard.

In truth, there's little in Alex Gibney's film that won't be familiar to attentive news watchers, but this skilled documentarian has mastered the art of condensing a vast and complex amount of information into a gripping and entertaining package.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Catfish will leave you with plenty of nagging questions, but whatever the truth behind the story, this is an extraordinary, provocative film and one that grips like a vice right up to the troubling and moving finale.

The tension between the conflicting worlds of Punk and Islam is only occasionally explored in any kind of satisfying way.

Mother is shot and edited with wonderful precision, and Bong continues to stun with his unerring ability to strike a perfect balance between the film's lighter and darker elements.
Underneath the glossy surface, Juan José Campanella's film is a rather silly and flabby thriller.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a deeply personal picture that's overflowing with exuberance and passion and is the director's best work in over twenty years.

Brody and Ruffalo are perfectly cast as the titular brothers, but the film is stolen by its female element, with both Weisz and Rinko Kikuchi on fine comic form.
Thompson fans should rejoice at seeing a film that truly captures the dark heart of this great novelist's work.
Green Zone begins with Shock and Awe, and Paul Greengrass tries to maintain that tone for the rest of the movie.
The film may be titled Kick-Ass, but this is Hit-Girl's movie all the way.
An acute study of psychological dislocation, which confirms [director] Martel's status as a distinctive and exciting filmmaker.

movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Of Gods and Men can be a little heavy-handed in its storytelling at times, but the confident direction and strong performances ensure it is an absorbing experience, and the beautiful final shot ends the film on a haunting note.

Yet another intriguing and surprising film from this ever-fascinating documentarian.

Thrillingly alive in a way that so few screen versions of Shakespeare manage to be.
Truly timeless.

These are good people and Loving is an important story, but that in itself is not quite enough.

Peter Fonda, Warren Oates and Verna Bloom build a complicated, touching, subtle triangle of longing and regret.
You should probably read the book instead.

movie_review_blurb: A head-spinning and often exhilarating mystery.

We'll miss you, Chantal.

A slight, touching film.

A forceful, funny, frightening and ingenious horror flick.

Those who like Beloved will file it under guilty pleasures.

Often rather moving...
Arguably the finest British film made during the second world war...

Long, loud, ludicrous, mindlessly enjoyable...
Delpy and Rock are naturally funny and the stuff good, lightweight sitcoms are made of.
There's a thin line between the exploration of grief and its exploitation that this film crosses.
Some teachers will learn from it. All teachers will find it a reaffirmation of their vocation.
Gripping...

Delaporte, a documentarist making her feature debut, breathes life into the scenes where the reluctant antiheroine is instructed in recognising fish and gutting them. The story however carries little conviction.

An affecting, unsentimental film with a strong central performance from Thomas Schubert.
This is Death in Venice African-style, though lacking the reticence and resonance of Mann's novella.
A nasty, efficient film that makes the imminent end of life on Earth seem like the judgment of a wise God.
A lame, sentimental enterprise.

The staging is meticulous.
McTeer's performance is one of the most convincing of its kind I've ever seen.

Damsels in Distress seems to be a metaphor for a society that has constantly been in need of authority and responsible leadership, and where since frontier days women have seen it as their duty to set standards and improve rebellious males.
A warts-and-all portrait of Hollywood at its zenith, a tale of how the bad created something beautiful.
As enjoyable a documentary as I've seen this past couple of years...
It's Kiplingesque nursery ethology, and one distrusts the editing.
I wish it were better, but it's more hardtack than Seabiscuit.
A rather dull offering - tasteful horror for the carriage trade.

A well-designed, tasteful affair.
Constance Marks's delightful, unpretentious documentary both captures the man in all his complex simplicity and throws light on his craft.

The perfect cast - Michael Redgrave, Michael Denison, Margaret Rutherford - and the perfect director (Anthony Asquith) know just how seriously (not very) to take this amoral satire on society's falsity.
A disturbing picture of a world in which television is taken for a "reality" higher than everyday life, it's also darkly funny.
Its glorious proliferation of magical transformations works like a charm on anyone who values the imagination.
Shaun of the Dead is an unexpected double joy: an unmissable English movie about the undead which is far from braindead and, simultaneously, a beautifully observed, very funny comedy.
A tragic tale that is well worth retelling.
Darfur Now has drawn criticism for its artless construction, and while it's true, he knows to step aside and let the passion of his subjects shine through.
In spite of the clunky package, the film's message really is a good one.
Both Miss Wood and Miss Moreno are permitted to work up fine fervors in their acting, and they come through.
Based on a men's mag article, Kyle Patrick Alvarez's debut feature is an honest, funny-sad portrayal of emotional dysfunction.

movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If the film lacks the social bite of Renoir's pre-war work, it's still a rich celebration of life and the director's own birthplace.

movie_title: L'année dernière à Marienbad (Last Year at Marienbad) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: It's all a tad schematic, and the direction is workmanlike but cautious.

A moving, compassionate film, shot with near Ozu-like restraint.

Flame-haired Jane Asher is enchanting as object of the hero's erotic obsession, and there's a bawdy cameo from a blowsy Diana Dors.
A worthy tribute to Bogdanovich's idols, Orson Welles and John Ford.

This is minimalist filmmaking at its most austere and effective.
A classic 1934 documentary from Robert Flaherty, pioneering forefather of the genre (see 1922's Nanook Of The North).

A harrowing study of loneliness that showcases an intensely brave and believable performance from newcomer del Carmen.

Nobody plays irascible, self-sabotaging schlubs better than Paul Giamatti.
Although he plays up the odd-couple comedy, Hooper knows how to bring out the anguish behind the humour.

Not only does it have the drop on the 1969 version, it's the first great movie of 2011.

Thought-stirring stuff -- but it tediously makes the same point over and over again.

This deliciously subversive 1932 social comedy kicked off Jean Renoir's greatest period.

Audran is luminous as the centre of a gentle, generous film about grace. Oh, and grub.

A superbly detailed account of a notorious miscarriage of justice and how it was gradually unravelled.
Another hefty slice of eastern european life - even longer, even slower and even glummer.
Depicts a drab, austerity-era East London of pinched lives and petty crime.
Four trivial stories, forced laughs: don't expect much more from Allen's latest postcard from Europe.
Another shrewdly gauged study of our capacity for deception and self-deception from A Separation's auteur. Emotionally devastating.
It's relentlessly downbeat and claustrophobic, but Ted Willis' script avoids easy recrimination.
It weaves games of dream and reality as the sextet wander through increasingly absurd set-ups. patriarchal authority and polite social rituals are slyly undermined, and the cast play it impeccably.

Overall, it might've worked better in a one-hour TV slot.
Tsai's long, static, near-wordless takes may try the patience of some, but fans will be enchanted by his new-found warmth.

Ultimately a gracious, even sweet-natured film, optimistic almost despite itself.

...although it reverts to slapstick for its set-piece chase finale, for most of its length Mark Illsley's debut film offers an unexpectedly gentle, even sentimental comedy of sexual identities...

Veber's film offers all the undemanding, solidly old-fashioned pleasures of a traditionally well-crafted French farce.

movie_review_blurb: A rich but satisfying plum-pudding.
The only downside is Armand Amar's over-explicit score, underlining every dramatic moment.

Well before the end the whole thing collapses into rip-roaring melodrama.
twisty substantial thriller, faithfully adapted from a standout BBC mini-series. It's not as exceptional as its source but the changes implemented mostly enhance rather than harm the story.
A film of dour but appealing charm.
Built around hand-held reportage, the film passes no judgement on the rightness or otherwise of the occupation. But the sense of bewilderment and futility speaks for itself.
The insidious humour and fascination with moral quandaries keep it consistently engrossing.
A luminous and resplendent visual masterpiece yoked to a puerile and embarrassingly trite plot.
A perceptive, empathetic character piece.

Where other Palestinian filmmakers have given vent to anger, grief or indignation over the travails of their people, Suleiman relies on a wry, deadpan gaze that recalls his mentor, Jacques Tati.
Forget heroics, forget glory -- this is war as fear and stench and panic.
Revanche (French for 'revenge') is that rarest of things -- a thoughtful thriller.
As character dynamics turn increasingly toxic all three actors excel, but Arterton is a revelation.
Writer/director Lu Chuan's film tells the whole harrowing story in austere black-and-white, sparing us nothing: the violence is indiscriminate and often horrifyingly casual.
Justin Kerrigan's first feature since 1999's Human Traffic is based on his own relationship with his father; no wonder it's so harrowing and deeply felt.
It's an intriguing premise - but this debut feature from short filmmakers Christine Molloy and Joe Lawlor never gets up to speed. It feels like a first draft, with some painfully stilted dialogue.

The mid-section drags slightly, but the cumulative effect is powerful, revealing what it's like to live in a society where even well-behaved kids can be crushed by the dictates of arbitrary, heavy-handed authority.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A sweet, lyrical treatment of the perennial 'woman from the sea' myth, well acted and beautifully shot amid Irish coastal landscapes. But the last degree of enchantment is missing.
It's all rather mannered and the final denouement is disappointingly banal.

An undeniably stirring, if predictable, account of how Nelson Mandela turned the Springbok team into a unifying force for his country. Non-rugby fans may find their patience tested, but Freeman's magisterial performance carries it.

Often touching, more often infuriating account of an ex-pat Brit journo in Oz exploring the how-to of father-son bonding. But even if you're grinding your teeth, the film's brash exuberance and its lead actor will keep you watching.
Another riveting insight into French thug life. The unsparing atmosphere - and Tahar Rahim's star-making turn - will sweep you along.
A compelling, saddening film.
No surprises in this account of the troubled pre-Beatles adolescence of John Lennon, but sharp scripting and a pair of outstanding performances lift it out of routine biopic territory.

A diverting period comedy-drama, but slight compared to Linklater at his sharpest. Worth catching, though, for newcomer Christian McKay's magisterial portrayal of the young Welles in all his moody, manipulative glory.
Not a comfortable watch... but still powerful and clear-eyed.

Quietly shedding all the fussy baggage of 'heritage drama', Campion gives us a moving account of Keats' great love and tragic death. A film of pictorial beauty and authenticity, graced with a fine cast.

Marco Bechis' crusading film sets up some fairly predictable clashes. But it's redeemed by the casting of actual Guarani tribespeople in the lead roles - and as actors, the Guarani prove themselves superb naturals.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Andrzej Jakimowski's gentle comedy has hazy, loopy summer charm by the bucketload, enough to make you overlook the often wayward plotting and shaky motivations.

This feature debut for co-directors Luis Piedrahita and Rodrigo Sopeña is never quite as clever as it thinks it is, and there are some sizeable holes in the plot. Still, with its teasing sense of play, you won't be crawling the walls.

Hausner subtly sketches in the characters involved -- the pilgrims, the carers, the bemused but conscientious resident priest -- and the tensions and jealousies that thrive in Lourdes' hothouse atmosphere, without ever showing her hand.
You'll have more fun staying at home.
movie_title: Chroniques sexuelles d'une famille d'aujourd'hui (Sexual Chronicles of a French Family) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An impressive film debut from fashion designer Tom Ford, with a career-best turn from Colin Firth. Misgivings about the too-perfect look are swept aside by its intelligence and emotional honesty.
A breezy, lightweight account of the making of a classic. Some of the casting may be questionable, but in the end it's the "cattle" who carry it.
Geens' first English-language feature builds slowly, piling up underlying darkness, hinting that further tragedy can't be far off.
With minimal resources, writer/directors Severin Fiala and Veronika Franz have crafted an insidious chiller, drawing measured performances from real-life twins Lukas and Elias Schwarz.
The offbeat teaming of Caine and Keitel anchors this wryly humorous Alpine-set fantasia, rich in beguiling images and suffused with a quiet, sensual melancholy.
Miller's NYC comedy bristles with wisecracks and quotable lines, while spinning a plot that sidesteps narrative cliché.
The action moves at the pace of the seasons; but for those who relax into its reflective mood, it offers much to savour.
What [Jabaly] shot vividly conveys the anger, grief and resilience of people trapped in a situation over which they have no control -- and the dedication (and humour) of the ambulance crew.
A lesser-known novel by Jane Austen becomes an auspicious foray into costume drama by Whit Stillman. Kate Beckinsale shines.
Playing out in real time, Theo and Hugo offers a warm, frank, unexpectedly romantic view of relationships today.
movie_title: Paris 05:59: Théo & Hugo (Théo et Hugo dans le même bateau) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The deliberate pacing risks trying our patience, but it's an accurate reflection of a system in stasis.
Sully is a skilfully made reconstruction of a recent real-life feat of heroic professionalism. But narrative tension is sorely lacking.
Leberecht plays games with vampire lore, but skirts around it with a subtlety and delicacy that lends his film emotional depths rare in low-budget horror.
How much of this is reportage, how much re-stagings, is anyone's guess. Much of the time, Josh is clearly sending himself up.
The story alternates between glorious canal scenery and Zac's woefully inept attempts to drum up help. An offbeat delight.
An offbeat, disruptive treatment of grief, shot through with flashes of manic humour, and played to the hilt by Jake Gyllenhaal at the top of his game.
Paloschi's film unsettles and inspires.
Acutely acted, The Fencer strikes home.
Nodding to The Conversation, this is an intriguingly controlled, highly original thriller.
Dark, gory and gruesome, this isn't kids' stuff. As a work of gothic imagination, it's a rare treat.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A gentle tale, tinged with melancholy told with all the loving attention to detail you expect from Studio Ghibli.

It has sometimes been suggested that there's little more to be said, in cinematic terms, [about the Holocaust].... The single-minded power and visceral immediacy of Nemes's achievement, rightly acclaimed and awarded, prove otherwise.
Political intrigue abounds as Spielberg grippingly recreates a famous real-life spy-swap case of the Cold War, with both Hanks and Rylance on top form.
The Irish expat experience, a poignant mix of aspiration and nostalgia, pervades Brooklyn, sensitively adapted by Nick Hornby from Colm Tóibín's 2009 prizewinning novel.
This is a film that never insists or over-stresses its effects, but works its way quietly and irresistibly into our emotions.
For all his often disenchanted outlook, Moretti's films almost always end on a positive note (however hard won). Mia madre is no exception.
Another witty dissection of social and sexual mores from perennial provocateur Ozon, deftly playing with the unpredictable complexities of desire.
Much of the film's humour is mined from its satirising of Jamie and Darby's retro-hipster lifestyle.
Making his first shot at feature direction, Russell Crowe homes in on a key trauma in Aussie history and brings it vividly to life.
This is sharp filmmaking, treating serious themes with a beguiling lightness.
Good, crude fun. But not much more than that.
Adventurer, narcissist or both? Marshall Curry's riveting study of a momma's boy turned freedom fighter never editorialises, leaving us to decide.

It's an intriguingly different take on the supernatural, with Eri Fukatsu and Tadanobu Asano appealing as the leads, but Kurosawa draws it out to the point of tedium. An overemphatic score doesn't help either.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Co-directors Alex Helfrecht and Jörg Tittel devise a convincingly scary dystopia crossing Nazi Germany with Stalin's Russia. Too bad Helfrecht's script lets it down.
It's when Churchill is at his most beleaguered that Darkest Hour spirals off into the further realms of fantasy.
An eye-catching, ideas-driven debut that turns its limited budget to its advantage, with shrewd lead performances.
An Oscar-aimed turn from Gary Oldman anchors this WW2 portrait of Churchill at his most beleaguered. Just mind the gap...
If there's one major oversight in this film, for all its epic scope, it's that despite its sincerely felt subject matter, everything is seen throughout from the viewpoint of the white folks.
The sets are detailed and charming, there are the usual lively, instantly forgettable songs, and several favourites (the Swedish Chef, Rowlf) show up in cheerful cameos.
From multi-talented Belgian/Canadian duo Dominique Abel and his partner Fiona Gordon comes a slice of light-hearted whimsy.
Impressive, sure, but ultimately stultifying.

Ms. Kidman goes through it all as if impersonating an adorable trick-or-treater.
Exquisitely acted, directed and photographed.

A mixed bag of goods. A bag of goods, it definitely is, but without a consistent point of view.

Even in the film's early, relatively enjoyable moments, you'll hear a small voice reminding you that there's a difference between a genuinely good movie and a merely watchable one. That pesky voice grows louder and louder with each scene.
Each scene is a masterwork of composition and execution.
The film is worth seeing, but it won't hold a cherished place in your moviegoing memories.
A space spectacle resonant with witty dialogue, accessible characters and kaleidoscopic action.
Undeniably great, the movie is not. But a good tonic, it is.

In this lovely and loving film, the comedy is mellow and the mood is intimate.
Technically, the film is a triumph.
It's a leisurely yet resonant film that reinforces the power of cinematic storytelling.

It's basically Mr. Brody's movie, and his performance is riveting.
Nothing is more uncool than trying too hard.
A comic train wreck consisting of limp dialogue, predictable plot twists and elaborate sight gags that fall flat.

A more-than-pleasant diversion.

Mr. Verbinski is an extremely skilled traffic director.

A memorable, haunting experience for moviegoers' eyes and hearts.

Traffics in such familiar territory as sibling rivalries, generational estrangements and broken dreams. But it slowly, sometimes too slowly, connects with the viewer.

Stay, it won't.

One of the few films to maintain an air of stuffiness even while sharing intimate details of debauchery.

Jen, poor Jen! Her unfriendly role requires her to act irritable and irritating for most of the footage.
Ultra-dumb.

An above-average thriller.

Over-acted, over-directed but dully directed.
Testimony to the power of old-style star wattage.

A superbly crafted curiosity piece.
Despite choppy, clunky moments, it leaves you with a smile.
A parade of cheap scare tactics.

You'll know better, but you'll still like it.
Long on heart but short on surprises.

A listless affair.

movie_review_blurb: The Polar Express is a stunning technological achievement and, for the most part, a stirring emotional one.
As character study, as exercise in American ambiance or, simply as an entertaining movie, Sideways triumphs.
Like its title character, the movie doesn't strive for depth. But it's stylish and, yes, also charming.

The 1930s touches, including a selection of background music, are beguiling.
Despite opportunities to turn soft and clammy, the film is moving but not maudlin, whimsical but not cloying.
Has some jolly good moments, buoyed by an intriguing story and an often dynamic cast.
A polished, feel-good movie that will be most appreciated by those who went back for second helpings of My Big Fat Greek Wedding.
Sadly, this predictable film will not mean as much to audiences as it obviously does to its creator.
Not a saga told with subtlety.
One-half a good movie. The second half goes wildly out-of-control, leaving the entire film in self-destructive mode.

It's pleasant, diverting and sweet.

A stunning mosaic of contradictions.
This one's no treasure. But it features a few interesting baubles.

The imaginatively cast, gorgeously designed movie has moments of wry wit and oddball charm. But its lumpish plot reinforces the suspicion that solid storytelling is no longer a Hollywood priority.

movie_review_blurb: Ocean's Twelve works like a short-term charm. In several years, you won't remember much about the movie except what a good time you had watching it.
With crackling dialogue, Closer reaches out and grabs all but the most reluctant viewer. Some spectators will be bored, but more will be shaken and stirred.

Alexander has aspirations of greatness, hoping to be christened an intellectual super-spectacle for brainy moviegoers. The sad truth is that it will probably numb more brain cells than it will stimulate.

Kingsley (Gandhi) and Connelly (A Beautiful Mind) both give magnetic, heartbreaking performances.
The joy of Master and Commander lies both in its roaring action and its emotional intricacies, a rare and great thing indeed for such a big-budget work.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's a misleadingly foreboding, cheaply scary and remarkably stupid thriller.
A very expensive, 73-minute commercial for related merchandise.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Elephant is probably one of the most realistic movies about high school ever made.
An improvement over DeVito's most recent effort, the universally reviled Death to Smoochy. However, what is funny in Duplex quickly devolves into mean-spirited gross-out humor.
For all its glossy, genuinely entertaining action, it's uncertain how long The Rundown will stick with you once you leave the theater. What is certain is this: The Rock has arrived as a movie star.
Unapologetically girly, drippingly romantic and, if you don't object to movies about female heartbreak and fate-with-a- capital-F, an entirely satisfying treasure to savor from start to finish.
If you're a gospel lover, you can probably overlook the technical flaws, especially if you see it in a crowded and enthusiastic theater.
Love Stinks exceeds its expectations.
Love and Basketball is never really more than an amiable Cinderella story, but it leavens its subject with such heart, such idealism and such pure eroticism that it's nearly a total success.
Never Been Kissed never makes it, but Barrymore's worth watching.
Where the Heart Is is everything that cynical moviegoers despise.
Ice Cube manages a certain bumbling charm that keeps the film churning along quite winningly for 90 minutes.
The main problem is that Morgan and Wong don't seem to have a clear idea of what they want -- campy, schlocky slasher flick or moody, intelligent thriller -- and as a result they create neither.
Watching Molly Shannon make out with a tree is amusing, but not even someone of her comic endurance can drag out that joke for the entire doddering length of Superstar.
A dream of a substantial production; a wisp of a movie that dissipates the moment you leave the theater.
Nearly reinvents the Muppet genre!
Look beyond the perfunctory dinosaur flatulence jokes, and Viva Rock Vegas is really quite sweet and clever.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: There is a terribly fine line between nihilism and rampant idiocy, and he hurls himself across it.
Even if it never turns out to be the most substantial movie, The Missing rarely stumbles in terms of entertainment value.
Koepp relies almost entirely on the isolated shocking images, ignoring the human element at the center in favor of digitalized special effects and rapid-fire editing.
The most amazing thing about Ready to Rumble is how bad it isn't.
Up at the Villa is a refined, tasteful film about pure, hard lust.
Whatever It Takes takes old tale, ruins it.

It's difficult for even the cynic in the audience to resist giggling at the sight of a grown man and a tiny-voiced Muppet arguing whether or not the Blanket an entire film has been built around should be called "Wubby" instead.
movie_title: The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Dickie Roberts, while certainly not a good movie, is a perfectly affable summer comedy, filled with nearly nonstop physical comedy and an impressive sprinkling of has-been celebrity cameos.
Harrowing and frequently brilliant.
Rodriguez ... has taken his work in 1995's Desperado, Mexico's precursor, and blown it up to mammoth, thrilling proportions.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that makes you think.
While the movie doesn't break any new ground, it is a consistently entertaining and relentlessly disgusting piece of work deserving of its own recognition.
Its success could indicate to studios that there is a market for intelligent, mature action films with prestige stars and directors.
Imbued with a blissful nostalgia for things that can never be recaptured, Lost in Translation is already poised to be one of the best movies of the year.
Deliberately, gleefully orchestrated camp.
A welcome return, even if it won't leave you entirely happy ever after.
There is nothing particularly wonderful about Timeline, but, other than Walker's acting, nothing particularly terrible about it, either.

What holds your attention most in Honey is not the treacly, pat story or even Alba's physical attributes. Rather, it's the boundless hilarity of watching the actress attempt to pull off lines like 'We just peoples.'
Fosters resentment by tricking you into thinking it's going somewhere much cleverer than it actually does.
In the first eight or so minutes, Snyder firmly grips you and rarely lets go.

Despite a brief distraction provided by some utterly gratuitous Jolie nudity, and a finale that is simultaneously riveting and idiotic, Taking Lives does not improve much on this season's crop of mediocre suspense films.
Kaufman, who is by far the most exciting screenwriter working today, has taken his trademark loopy storytelling and transformed it into something more mature and wonderful.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Jay and Silent Bob fans may weep, but for pretty much everyone else, there's cause to rejoice.

The chemistry between Hanks and Hall is the strongest element of the movie. Both are lavishly ornamented characters -- caricatures, really, but not in an off-putting way -- who play marvelously off each other.
The movie is also far from a train wreck. In fact, at times, it's even kind of ... OK.
This is a fairy tale in desperate need of some better magic.
Leland is absolutely interesting. But it's never genuinely good, or even all that memorable.
The movie is good entertainment for the younger-than-14 set. But it's not quite inventive or spectacular enough to fully charm anyone older.
A movie that inspires little but boredom and faint irritation.
While Vol. 2 has its breathtaking moments, it is self-indulgent, unmemorable and almost completely uninvolving.
A lot more solid and engaging than its premise might have you believe.
The Singing Forest is not just incompetently written, directed and performed, it's also breezily offensive.
You don't so much enjoy watching it as you simply appreciate the genius that went into its creation.

Writer-director Nir Bergman, in his feature film debut, captures this fractured family's halting attempts to put itself back together again with compassion and intelligence, drawing understated performances from his entire cast.
Garner's heretofore unexploited comedic prowess is what catapults 13 Going on 30 from passably entertaining to highly watchable.
A clever, if not terribly enduring, romantic comedy.
Easily the dumbest thriller to be released since last month's Taking Lives.
Enjoyable and surprisingly touching.
A trenchantly observed, bitingly witty comedy about just how mean girls can be.
An excellent example of filmmakers throwing bundles of money at a proverbial wall and seeing what sticks.
As the seasons pass, lessons are learned, mistakes are made and, inevitably, many audience members are put to sleep.
The action of Spartan is so choppy, the transitions so abrupt, and the pacing so deadeningly unvarying, the movie musters little suspense.
Much like the big-screen adaptation of Charlie's Angels, Starksy & Hutch manages to play its cheeseball aspects with a perfect balance of sincerity and irony, cleverness and idiocy.
Twisted, despite managing tiny, sad bursts of suspense, is barely worth the energy it will take to mock it.
Moderately entertaining but droopy romance.

... is likely to disappoint die-hard fans of the writing/directing team's established gross-out humor, but pleasantly surprise those looking for a comedy with a sweeter, though still unintimidatingly low-brow, center.
Despite the fact that it never seems particularly fresh, Way Off Broadway is consistently funny.
To paraphrase a key line of Nicholson's, Something's Gotta Give is a movie to love.
A movie in which all problems have the complexity of a pleated skirt and can be solved with a heartfelt hug, and all characters fit dull and predictable molds.
Lovely and unusual -- a fresh, genuinely moving story populated by fully realized characters.
The familiar story is not entirely bereft of flashes of reinvigoration, but they're few and far between.
A work of palpable passion, fueled by tremendous performances, and it's among the best movies of the year.
Blazingly stupid, punishingly dull.
Better than anything Burton has made in years, but it is never completely what a good story should be: compulsively entertaining.
Brilliantly acted but maddeningly structured.
Like Moore herself, it's kind of sweet, but mostly bland.
This coal-black comedy provokes frequent laughs, but many of its jokes feel downright cruel.
A stirring, brutal and sad examination of the bleak cycle of violence and pain.
The movie is occasionally absorbing but more often boring.
Clumsy plot developments carried out by characters you already know from a series of other movies.
[A] decent but often inert movie.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Triplets is very probably unlike anything you've seen before.
Girl With a Pearl Earring is a lot like watching exceptionally pretty paint dry.
It's the chemistry between all the characters, which has deepened since the first movie, that makes Barbershop 2 worth watching despite its sluggish, sometimes sloppy pace.
Shamelessly manipulative but thoroughly enjoyable.
While it's not his best work, it's certainly not the worst thing Sandler has made.
Ryan may yet have a movie in her that will match the critical and commercial success of the 15-year-old When Harry Met Sally ..., but Against the Ropes isn't it.
The movie is way too long, way too dull and way too unfunny.

Manages to be somewhat compelling until it crashes and burns in a ridiculous finale.
Finding Home may have been created with a lot of sincerity and heart, but little of it comes through to the audience.
No actress has been as purely delightful to watch all year as Dench is tromping her way through this effervescent comedy, which falters only during its inevitably somber final act.
A staggeringly lazy, leg-twitchingly dull, unholy mess.
A movie whose charm and wit sneak up on you.
He [director Allen Coulter] is clearly reaching for more than he ultimately achieves with this project, but it's a strong effort nonetheless, a warm throwback to the golden era of Hollywood.
Nothing in The Last Kiss is particularly revelatory, but strong performances -- Braff continues to cement his status as an unlikely heartthrob -- make it a pleasure to watch.
Despite all its exhausting striving, All the King's Men is simply not a great, or even good, movie.
The filmmaker, working from his own script for the first time, is so joyful, so ebullient, that he manages to skirt pretentiousness even when the movie becomes oppressively whimsical.

In fact, there may well have been one or two funny lines in Man of the Year, but by that point they were lost in the staggering repulsiveness.
A chilling and fascinating look at the ever-increasing power of the organized Religious Right.
A terrifically engaging biopic of 1970s Ugandan dictator Idi Amin, who is played with the sort of extraordinary yet restrained force that only great actors like Forest Whitaker can manage.
Too broad to be a truly great film, but it does cheerily give lie to the assumption that the limits of Capote meant there was no reason to rehash this same story.

Coppola has not made the anticipated period piece or even character study. Her third film, instead, is all about mood: artfully capturing the anxieties inherent in being a young, confused woman far from home.
Eastwood keeps the complex story steady, demonstrating equal aptitude for filming cataclysmic battle sequences and intimate scenes of dialogue.
[The Nolan brothers] have collaborated on a script that is sometimes on target, but hopelessly hamstrung by a wobbly second half for which its grand finale cannot compensate.
Noyce has sculpted a powerful and resonant portrait of a country gone insane trying to hold tightly to an intrinsically racist and immoral law.
Highly enjoyable.
Taken as a whole, Running With Scissors is dysfunction rendered lovingly and gracefully.
For the viewer with the appropriately inappropriate sense of humor, Borat -- despite being an undeniable novelty -- is also irresistible.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping, patient and utterly enchanting, it is a marked growth for Iñárritu and Arriaga, who have taken a precarious conceit and transformed it into one of the most powerful movies of the year.

If you've really paid attention to Ferrell's career, this role is not a stretch. He brings great humanity to a character, and a movie, that ends up being more of a sentimental romance than the silly quirk-fest you might expect.
Casino Royale proves that back to basics is a good place to be -- unless you end up aping the same incongruous spirit that hobbled your predecessor.

[Director] Linklater maintains his usual effortless, laid-back charm while railing against corrupt industry as a whole. (Even when you're being hammered over the head with some point, it's usually a quiet, polite sort of hammering.)
... not entirely sure what it wants to be.
The opening half-hour of Idlewild is perhaps the most entrancing of any movie so far this year, which is why it's all the more frustrating that what follows is of such uneven quality.
... riveting documentary ...
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The greatest title in history is, when executed as an actual movie, venomously awful.
Lurking somewhere inside the high-concept sloppiness of Accepted is the kernel of a solid comedy.
To Gore's credit, he is using this film to promote something other than himself (although, granted, that is a nifty side effect). He does seem to truly care about the world in which we live.

This could all be a miserable mess, but it works, somehow.
Nacho Libre, with its relatively (and refreshingly) tame PG rating, is likely to thrill boys under 13. But it may also evoke laughs even if you're far removed from that demographic.
An intriguing -- if not indelible -- portrait of the difficulty of being not just an adolescent, but the parent of one.
The biggest problem with Click is not that it isn't funny, but that the moments worthy of laughs often feel isolated from the sloppily assembled plot.
A movie that is cheerfully, indiscriminately violent, exploiting exactly the same viciously cyclical culture on which it pretends to be providing trenchant commentary.
At every turn in Superman Returns is a sense of respect for all that's preceded it.
Saying The Devil Wears Prada is superior to the book on which it is based is like saying that devouring chocolate is better than seeing its grimy residue smudged on a napkin.

If you're the kind of person who has never attempted a crossword more challenging than the celebrity-themed puzzles found in the back of Star magazine, it's remarkable how gripping and just plain fun you'll find Wordplay.
Dead Man's Chest has every appearance of an epic adventure, but not the soul of one.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, you may cringe, or shudder, or even wonder when your tastes became quite this puerile, but Strangers With Candy is a long-awaited treasure of ludicrousness with very few dead spots.

My Super Ex-Girlfriend falls somewhere in the middle of Reitman's quality spectrum.
All [Shyamalan's] films, to their credit, have been unswervingly sincere. But the primary problem is that this movie is so earnest, you can't help but gag on it.
It's equal parts funny and frightening, and should, like its two-decades-old predecessors, turn into a slumber-party staple. But really -- you must be this tall to ride this ride.
It's got smarts, snark and simple sweet-and-sour goodness.
Miami Vice is about as hip as a marathon session of Uno.
Scoop, a self-consciously wacky crime comedy that retains from Match Point both the English backdrop and star Scarlett Johansson.
As gripping as The Night Listener wants to be, it's also nearly devoid of suspense because you know it's supposed to be suspenseful.
The Descent isn't perfect, or even entirely original...But it's a lot better, and fresher, than it would be if (or, gulp, when) Hollywood chews it up and spits it out again.
Talladega Nights is the rare comedy that manages to be funny and witty.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: World Trade Center is a commemoration of everyone who lost his or her life in the wreckage of 9-11, but also something more. It's a celebration of living, against all odds.
We can celebrate not just all that Little Miss Sunshine achieves, but, more importantly, what it avoids.
What's strange about The Break-Up is that, despite the alleged deep love between Gary and Brooke, you never get the sense that much is at stake.
It's not that a lot of the content isn't really, really funny -- but it isn't exactly fresh, either.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For Your Consideration is far from a failure, because Guest rounds up his usual sprawling ensemble to provide a variety of superb supporting parts.
The hilariously bombastic story about the ancient Battle of Thermopylae is very much like spending two hours watching someone play a video game.

Deserves to be celebrated as a work that comes closer than any other to achieving what the filmmaker does best: Reminding us that no matter what is happening on a larger scale, we are defined by our interpersonal relationships.
The movie does deserve credit for sticking to an ending no one at the studio could have wanted. We would, however, like to premonish that the conclusion is equally unlikely to satisfy the audience.
There are just enough great lines to keep this uneven comedy from devolving into a complete mess, but it never coalesces into anything of substance or real quality.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Pride is so unapologetically earnest in its inspirational values, you either want to love it or kill it.
Shooter is a well-timed reminder that cinematic violence can qualify as something other than mindless -- it can even, in deft hands, be mindful.

Further proof that every movie is better when it has zombies in it, Planet Terror also demonstrates that every movie is better when it features a retired stripper/aspiring stand-up comedian with a machine gun in place of her freshly amputated leg.
Twisty, quite fun and generally bereft of sentimentality. It is, in short, just about the last movie you'd expect Lasse Hallström to make.
Perfect Stranger is Halle Berry's latest descent into career purgatory.
Not high art, but it serves its purpose.

It's been quite a few years since we've had an intelligent, engaging legal thriller. Into the void slips Fracture, which fits the bill thanks to a polished script, great stars and a director perfectly suited for this territory.
When it comes to a movie as consistently hilarious as Hot Fuzz, it's better to have too much of a good thing than too little.
The best installment of the saga yet, in large part because its villains are so much more compelling than those past.
By all rights, this should be terrible -- but it's not. It's simply mediocre.

There are a lot of offensive things about Gringo Wedding, an ostensible romantic comedy partially made in South Florida. It's racist, sexist and homophobic. But perhaps most galling is how stupid it is.
Many things happen in 28 Weeks Later, but you watch all of them with a sense of detachment. There is idle curiosity about who will be killed next, and how, but no real investment in their fates.

A far better, more absorbing melodrama than its titular conceit would have you expect.
Heartrending, elegant and restrained, Away From Her is a wonderful showcase for not just Christie and the rest of its powerful cast, but for Polley's multidimensional skills.

Waitress shows Shelly, just 40 when she was killed, to be a filmmaker of poise and promise. It's tragic that promise was never realized beyond this sweet, if slight, project -- but still a decent tribute to Shelly's multifaceted abilities.

There's a big difference between slowly unfurling a difficult story so that it rewards a patient audience, and simply teasing viewers nearly to the point of torture. The Golden Door [skirts] dangerously close to the torturous.
...A movie that has consistently entertained audiences on the festival circuit since its premiere at Tribeca in April.
Somehow Full of It got made and got distributed, despite its nearly fanatical lack of wit or originality.

By all rights, such a slapdash formula shouldn't work. And yet, this is a movie that gives fans of the show pretty much everything they could want.

You could dog-ear the pages of every thesaurus imaginable, though, and still not be able to capture the visceral power that Gibson presents. You just have to see it.
A ragged but extremely amiable family comedy.
Heart ... puddle ... on floor.
Rocky Balboa works as a decent nostalgia piece and sports drama.

It's not that We Are Marshall does anything groundbreaking -- and that dependability is part of its appeal. It's an undeniably compelling story, and maybe it would make you cry just as hard even if it weren't gracefully told.
Many things happen in The Good Shepherd, but very few of them are especially interesting or, more to the point, memorable.
Volver is a rapturous, freewheeling valentine to the [female] gender as a whole, and as luxuriously voluptuous as the women who populate it.

What [director] Condon cannot do is instill in Dreamgirls any beguiling qualities, any magic that would make even those resistant to musicals fall under its spell.

The story, despite its nominally fascinating nature, never barrels forth the way it needs to. It plods. How a director as versatile and inventive as Cuarón managed that is a mystery greater than any found in the film.

This is the kind of film so joyful you can imagine watching it again and again. Anytime you come away from such ultimately dark subject matter suffused with happy appreciation, you know you've stumbled on something special.
It's rare to encounter a movie as aggressive in its ridiculousness as Perfume: The Story of a Murderer. So, credit where credit is due: This is an extremely ambitious terrible film.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Even though Stomp the Yard is, at heart, kind of undeniably silly (the rival frats are rather Sharks-Jets), it's an irresistible brand of silliness.

How far the bite-y have fallen.

A quietly fascinating and intelligent story about betrayal.

It's dumb as rocks and thoroughly unnecessary.
Cronicas as a whole doesn't engender much gravity, because its central theme is so inane.
Clumsy, dumb, offensive drama.
Broken Flowers is ultimately more interesting than it is good.
Deeply foul and painfully funny.
A fun, suspenseful romp, thanks to good acting and an even better, economic 85-minute running time.
The 40-Year-Old Virgin is one of the best comedies ever made.
While this sweet-tart movie is definitely worth seeing, more compelling is what Morrison, and Adams, will do next.
For those open to the experience, it's a spellbinding, hypnotic masterpiece.

Blessed with crisp dialogue, bright wit and a strong lead performance.
A genuinely touching story about how a woman can use her intelligence to overcome tough situations. Take your mom, or your daughter.

movie_review_blurb: In its own unassuming, self-effacing way, Serenity is the epic sci-fi adventure that the latter years of Star Wars could only dream of being.
A film that manages to be gorgeous, scary, sexy and vicious, all at once.
Salles takes an approach to building tension best described as methodical, which to many viewers is going to translate simply to 'boring.'
A funny, warm and mostly smart depiction of familial relations. It may not be a perfectly cohesive whole. But for anyone looking for a pleasure you don't have to feel too guilty about, it'll do.

War of the Worlds is easily the most bone-chillingly scary movie Spielberg has made, but it also taps into an unsettling kind of fear that never goes for the cheap thrill. The dread Spielberg conjures is horribly personal.
A film desperately trying to distract you from how little there is behind it.
Look at Me is sly, discomfiting and a great exploration of fame and beauty.
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As embarrassingly guilty pleasures go, House of Wax does a decent job of molding itself to your needs.

A thoroughly compelling suspense film. That doesn't mean it isn't kind of dumb, or largely ridiculous -- it is both -- but here dumb ridiculousness has been elevated to an art form.
Revenge of the Sith is both unspeakably brilliant and kind of OK, depending on where you're coming from.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's a solid effort with a broad reach.
Thanks to great Dames Dench and Smith, and the hushed, softly humorous performance by Bruhl, it's a consistently entertaining, often subtly lovely drama.
It's nice to look at, but lacks a sense of purpose.
The Longest Yard is not a terrible movie, but neither is it one with any value beyond the disposable.
Howard has tapped into a glorious true-life story and wisely chosen Crowe, an unparalleled actor, to embody the hero.

This documentary is the most skillful, exhaustive and appealing film so far this century about corporate corruption.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: 3-D is awful. It's annoying, and tiresome, and stupid. If you are an adult, it is bearable for about five minutes, if that. Then you will probably feel the need to close your eyes. Forever.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: High Tension thrills you with its bare bones brutality. Then it infuriates you when it abandons the purity of the story for a gimmick.
Not only easily the best Batman movie to date, but also one that will be nearly as entertaining to audiences who've never cracked a comic book as it will to fans.
A movie this insipid somehow makes Herbie: Fully Loaded seem promising in comparison.

The acting is sloppy, the story convoluted, the finale anticlimactic. But because this is not just a zombie movie, but one made by the undisputed zombie master, it's easier to forgive the lapses.
Spielmann ensures only that audiences will be seriously bored.
Both a celebration of a time long past and an acknowledgement of the romanticized, whitewashed fantasies of that same past, especially when it's held up to the harsh light of today.
